    Comprehensive Collection of Ancient and Modern Books: Volume 377

    Surgery: External Injuries and Broken Bones

    Huang Di's Suwen

    On the Essentials of Pulse Diagnosis

    The liver pulse is firm and long, but the color is not blue; this indicates the condition is due to a fall or impact. Blood is retained beneath the ribs, causing shortness of breath. (Note: The liver governs blood and color; when the pulse is strong but color is not visible, it indicates blood is stored below. The condition arises from falls or injuries caused by impacts, leading to blood clotted under the ribs, hence the shortness of breath.)

    Jinkui Yaolüe (Han Dynasty, Zhang Ji)

    On the Pulse Signs of Severe Wounds

    The pulse at the inch is slightly floating and weak; it indicates loss of blood, similar to sweating. If there is no sweating, the body has wounds caused by knives or axes, resulting in loss of blood.

    Pulse Classics (Jin Dynasty, Wang Shuhe)

    On the Pulse

    If one falls from a height and has internal bleeding, with abdominal distension, a firm pulse indicates survival; a weak pulse indicates death. If the bleeding from a severe wound is excessive, a weak and fine pulse suggests survival, while a strong and frequent pulse indicates death. If there is bleeding from a severe wound and the pulse is small and deep, survival is more likely; if it is floating and strong, death is likely. If a cut causes bleeding of one or two sheng (a unit of weight), a strong pulse indicates death within twenty days. For continuous bleeding from cuts, a strong and frequent pulse indicates death within seven days; a smooth and fine pulse indicates survival.[1p]
    Thousand Gold Formula - Sun Simiao

    For Treating Injuries from Blows

    Whenever one is injured from a blow, if blood stagnates and the heart feels compressed, making it impossible to speak, one can pry open the mouth and let urine run into it to induce revival. Similarly, for those who have fallen from a carriage or horse, or have been crushed under wheels and appear dead, one should place the deceased comfortably and cover the mouth, nose, and eyes with a sleeve for a brief moment. After a short while, they may live again, opening their eyes and producing warm urine.

    For Treating Metal Wounds

    To treat metal wounds, regardless of size or season, as soon as the injury occurs and blood flows, one should apply a thick layer of lime to stop the pain and promote quick healing. If lime is unavailable, ash may be used instead. If the wound is very deep and should not heal quickly, add a bit of talcum powder to prevent closure. Generally, when metal wounds bleed, the person will feel thirsty and should endure it. Eating dry foods or fatty foods to quench the thirst is advised, while avoiding salty foods. If one consumes too much porridge or gruel, it can cause blood to flow excessively and be lethal. Additionally, it is crucial to avoid anger, loud talking, laughter, speculation on yin and yang, physical labor, excessive consumption of sour or salty foods, hot alcohol, and other similar things. Even after the wound heals, these precautions should be observed for at least a hundred days to half a year before returning to normal activities.

    Hexi Six Writings - Liu Wansuo[2p]
    On Tetanus

    Wind diseases are the beginning of all ailments. When the body is clear and calm, the pores are closed and protected; thus, even when faced with harsh winds and poisons, they cannot cause harm. Hence, tetanus aligns with both the exterior and interior, differentiating between yin and yang, and is treated similarly to typhoid. In humble villages, there are often those who lack knowledge. They only recognize external manifestations and are unaware of conditions that affect the interior or require harmonization. This includes the methods of sweating, purging, and harmonizing, which also align with typhoid symptoms. There are those with conditions on the surface, those within, and those in between. For internal issues, purging is appropriate; for surface conditions, sweating is suitable; and for those in between, harmonization is best. However, sweating and purging must not exceed their limits. Thus, tetanus arises from outside to inside, with more severe internal symptoms indicating a more serious illness. Consequently, injuries from sudden trauma, alongside wind attacks, propagate through the meridians, causing alternating chills and fever, leading to a tightened body and an inability to open the mouth. In severe cases, malign energy enters the organs, necessitating purgative treatment. No sores heal, the vitality is weak, and the flesh does not regenerate; the openings of sores do not close properly, allowing wind pathogens to enter from the outside, resulting in tetanus-like symptoms, hence no sores heal. Alas! The world commonly claims that moxibustion is supreme, but fails to realize that heat from fire and toxic influences disrupt the meridians, leading to countless variations. Mild cases may cause fever, while severe cases can induce wind and spasms, or lead to bent limbs and inability to open the mouth or misaligned eyes, all due to the stagnation of energy and vitality from the sores, preventing proper circulation. There are also cases of tetanus without moxibustion treatment. When a sore has white scabs, the opening closes up, making it difficult for energy to flow and drain; thus, yang heat easily becomes stagnant, and excessive heat can give rise to wind.[3p]
    Therefore, a floating pulse that is weak indicates the Taiyang (greater yang), a long and strong pulse indicates the Yangming (bright yang), and a floating and thin pulse indicates the Shaoyang (lesser yang). For Taiyang, sweating is appropriate; for Yangming, purging is suitable; and for Shaoyang, harmonizing is the way. If one understands these three methods, and treats without matching the illness, it has never been the case.

    For tetanus, when wind-heat is severe and there is stagnation at the surface, but the interior Qi remains balanced, there may be good extension of pulses, with tendons and pulses tight; sometimes there can be a feeling of cold or spasms, with floating, rapid, and thin pulses. In such cases, it is advisable to use warming and spicy herbs to treat the wind, releasing the blockage and achieving recovery. This is akin to treating a surface heat and stagnation of wind-cold with Ma Huang Decoction for warming and dispersing.

    In general, when using warming and spicy herbs to open wind-heat stagnation, it is beneficial to assist with cooling herbs to avoid causing illness with the medicinal herbs and worsening the wind-heat condition.[4p]
    For treating febrile diseases, herbs such as ephedra, cinnamon twig, huangqin (scutellaria), zhi mu (anemarrhena), and gypsum may be used. If only licorice, talc, green onions, and fermented soybeans are used, they can effectively disperse cold. If the exterior symptoms persist and gradually progress inward, with a slight, wiry pulse indicating that the interior is not yet severely disturbed, one should use herbs to dispel wind-heat and alleviate the stagnant cold, or slightly add dispersing, pungent, and warming herbs. This is akin to using Xiao Chai Hu Tang (Minor Bupleurum Decoction) to harmonize when the condition is half exterior and half interior. If the interior condition is severe, with a stiff tongue, locked jaws, backward-arching neck and back, restlessness, spasms, thick and sticky saliva, a feeling of fullness in the chest and abdomen, constipation, or intermittent sweating, with a pulse that is deep, forceful, rapid, and wiry, this indicates that the sweat is caused by wind-heat severely affecting the interior, and the exterior heat has somewhat subsided. Consequently, the pores are open and heart fire is intense, leading to sweating. The treatment principle should involve dispelling wind and relieving the cold blockage, and then applying herbs to dispel wind-heat and alleviate stagnation, allowing the heat to recede, the blockage to disperse, and restoring health.[5p]

    Essentials of Living: On Falling Injuries

    When one falls from a height, bad blood accumulates internally and affects the twelve meridians. Physicians often diagnose this as a wind-attack on the liver meridian, with symptoms manifesting in the lower ribs. Blood is primarily governed by the liver, and bad blood will inevitably return to the liver, regardless of which meridian is affected, as the liver is the master of blood. If there is severe pain, it will likely cause sweating. However, since everyone sweats, this is associated with wind disorders, all of which belong to the liver wood. Moreover, with stagnant blood congealed, it counteracts its proper place and enters the liver.

    In cases of falling from a height, the upward-acting blood and qi are disturbed; this is attributed to the liver. If there is no sweating, it may not be a cold injury, but once there is sweating, it must be influenced by wind, thus requiring treatment with blood-dispersing herbs.

    In situations involving fall from a height or blunt force trauma, where there is accumulated stagnant blood in the chest and abdomen, it is essential to differentiate between the upper, middle, and lower jiao (organs). For the upper region, use formulas like Lao Xijiao Di Huang Decoction. For the middle, use Taoren Chengqi Decoction. For the lower area, something like Didao Decoction can be prescribed. Additionally, these can be combined with urines or wine for decoction.

    There are also methods that include raw Rehmannia and Angelica in the decoctions, or those that combine with Da Huang. Individuals with deficiency who cannot withstand purgation may take Siwu Decoction with added pangolin for effective treatment. There's also Huasui Shi San, which can be prepared with a boy’s urine or taken with wine.

    This medicine pairs with previous cold-reducing remedies, emphasizing the importance of discerning between yin and yang. Once the stagnant blood has been resolved, one can take Fuyuantongqi San with added Angelica for further benefit.[6p]
    Danxi's Heart Method
    (Yuan - Zhu Zhenheng)

    Trauma and Injuries

    For injuries from falls and impacts, one should use Su Mu to invigorate the blood, Huang Lian to reduce heat, Bai Zhu to harmonize the middle, and prepare a decoction of boy's urine. For injuries below the diaphragm, one should first restore connection and then eliminate the stagnant blood; for those above, it is advisable to drink juice from leeks or consume it mixed with porridge. It is crucial not to drink cold water. If blood encounters cold, it will congeal, and even a single drop of blood entering the heart can lead to death.
    Tetanus[7p]
    Tetanus often results in death; treatment should include wind prevention and scorpions among other remedies. Scorpions are essential; ten should be powdered and mixed with wine, taken three times a day. For blood coagulation and heart issues related to tetanus, burn crow's wings to ash, grind fine, and mix with one qian (about 3.3 grams) of wine.

    Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment
    (Ming Dynasty, Dai Sigong)

    Falls and Struggles

    A fall is called a "diān" when one doesn't know it, and "pū" when two clash; both result in harm. Those who are dizzy and mentally disturbed from falls and struggles can take Su He Xiang pills mixed with wine, or Jing Ming powder, or a Qi Harmonizing drink with a bit of rhubarb boiled and mixed with vinegar; or use children’s urine to mix with the black spirit powder (or substitute it with liquor boiled with sandalwood). For pain from falls and struggles, mixing wine with amber powder is excellent. Additionally, use Wu Yao to regulate Qi, especially effective for back pain due to falls. If individuals who have fallen take medicine and use inhalation and topical applications without effect, advise them to use equal parts of white peony, red peony, Wei Ling Xian, frankincense, and myrrh, grind them to fine powder, mix with wine and take; this will immediately relieve half of the pain.

    Knife Wounds

    For knife wounds with uncontrollable bleeding, use only white peony powder mixed with white wine, and apply the powder directly to the wound. If the blood is not flowing freely and is causing stagnation with redness and swelling at the wound, or affecting limbs and head, consider using Jing Ming powder or boiling safflower mixed with black spirit powder. If there is difficult-to-stop bleeding, use dragon bone and frankincense in equal parts, ground to powder and pressed into the affected area; using snake fish grass as a poultice is especially effective. This method is not only good for knife wounds but also for continuous bleeding from falls.[8p]
    Tetanus

    The "Inner Canon" states: Wind is the source of all diseases. When the body is clear and pure, the pores are closed, and even strong winds or toxic influences cannot cause harm. However, concerning tetanus, injuries that break the skin and flesh are often regarded as ordinary matters. Little do people realize that the wind pathogen takes advantage of this vulnerability to invade, gradually turning into a severe condition. If sores do not heal properly, the wind pathogen can also invade from within. Whether through bathing in decoctions or cauterizing with moxa, the toxic gas from these methods is not different from the tetanus pathogen. The symptoms can spread through the meridians, burning the vital energy; hence, alternating cold and heat occurs. In severe cases, the jaw may lock, eyes may become misaligned, and the body becomes rigid, resembling a bow drawn tight, leading to death in a short time, which is indeed pitiable.

    The method of treatment should align with that of typhoid fever since there are three differing conditions: on the surface, internally, or a combination of both. Therefore, treatment involves sweating for surface conditions, purging for internal conditions, and harmonizing for cases in between. Moreover, one should not exceed these methods. Common folks often do not recognize this condition, making it easy to result in fatality. Delaying medical attention while waiting for the outcome is truly tragic![9p]
    Introduction to Medicine 【Ming Dynasty, Li Zhan】

    Fractures

    Fractures can injure the body, whether from falls, blows, or crushing, causing qi and blood to stagnate and break. Injuries from sharp metal or cuts that cause external bleeding can be treated; however, injuries to internal organs, membranes, or the Yin substance behind the ears are untreatable.

    For those who have not bled, it is advisable to use lithospermum to resolve stagnation, Coptis to reduce fire, and Atractylodes to harmonize the middle. These three ingredients should be combined with children’s urine and boiled in wine for oral administration. Those with upper body injuries should consume it with leeks and porridge, while those with lower body injuries may take it directly. If the blood is cold, it will coagulate; one must not drink cold water, as blood entering the heart leads to death.

    For resolving stagnation, one can use the Rooster Call Powder, Flower Bud Stone Powder, or Fragrant Wood Qi Harmonization Powder, mixed with children’s urine, red yeast rice, or red wine. If there has been bleeding, quickly use Chen Wang Dan to stop the bleeding. Begin with tonic medicines before resolving stagnation. In cases of extreme deficiency, one must also avoid purging. For blood deficiency, Four Substance Decoction with added pangolin should be used. For Qi deficiency, one may take lithospermum, ginseng, astragalus, danggui, tangerine peel, and licorice for half a month; if the pulse becomes less scattered, one can cautiously take an herbal decoction mixed with natural copper powder on an empty stomach, avoiding it if the bone is not fractured. For substantial deficiency, use purple river car and eliminate musk.[10p]
    In cases of injury, the essence lies in replenishing qi and blood; if affected by cold, one should first disperse the cold. Blood issues from injuries primarily pertain to blood itself, unlike the six excesses or seven emotions, which have distinctions in relation to qi and blood. However, since the liver governs blood, regardless of the meridian affected, any stagnant blood will inevitably return to the liver, flowing to the side and causing accumulation in the abdomen, resulting in distension and pain, or alternating cold and heat. In cases of excess, one should purgative; in cases of deficiency, one should use whether to disperse or to restore with blood-activating decoctions, or with the Shiquan Dabu Decoction, adding ingredients like Xiangfu, Chenpi, and Fritillaria in equal parts, decocted in water for consumption.

    When an injury suddenly dries out at the wound, and toxins attack internally, leading to confusion, vexation, nausea, and significant bleeding along with persistent vomiting of blood, these are difficult to treat. For early vomiting, use Pingwei Powder taken internally, and apply ginger juice externally. For tetanus-related swelling, Jiangtiao Pills are indicated; if qi is weak, only the honey guiding method should be utilized.

    Whether due to excessive initial bleeding or early closure of the wound, leading to stagnant blood, it is all indicative of blood being affected. Blood is yin, governed by the five zang organs; though it may initially be superficial, it quickly penetrates inward, often resulting in death. Therefore, nourishing blood with decoctions like Danggui Dihuang Tang, Huoshen Dan, Tuo Li San, and Neituo Shixuan San can prevent toxin infiltration. Externally, use fish bladder powder, or grind mouse skull into powder and mix with lard for application.[11p]
    Injury and Trauma

    If there is injury accompanied by water retention and a stiff, locked jaw, apply ground oyster as a poultice and take a decoction of licorice, two qian in dosage. Sometimes, a patient may appear to have recovered significantly, only to suddenly experience a stiff jaw and convulsions with phlegm blockage, resembling tetanus or convulsions, but in reality, it is due to deficiency of both qi and blood.

    After the rupture and drainage of boils or abscesses, if there is a significant loss of pus and blood, yin disperses and transforms the condition; thus, it is essential to greatly replenish qi and blood. If it truly is a case of wind-tetanus, it is also inappropriate to treat with wind-dispelling medicines.

    For those with blood deficiency, use the Four Substances Decoction with added ginseng and atractylodes. For qi deficiency, use the Middle Reinforcing Elixir without spolidang and dried orange peel, adding toasted black berberine, schisandra, ophiopogon, and cinnamon in large doses.

    If both qi and blood are deficient, with excessive sweating, thirst, and cold or heat sensations, use the Complete Vitality Decoction, adding cinnamon, aconite, ophiopogon, and schisandra. For hiccups, administer the Warm Middle Decoction. Should one recklessly administer wind-dispelling medications, it may lead to death.[12p]
    Zhang Chuang (Blister from Beating)

    Zhang Chuang should not be treated according to the law. According to ancient methods, breaking the stasis and expelling blood is the priority. After one stroke, drink a mixture of children's urine and wine; do not consume tea to avoid aggravating the heart with blood. Once the spirit has settled, for those with a robust physique, use Ji Ming San to assist. For those with a weaker constitution, if the sore brings about cold and heat, nausea, or reduced appetite, it is advisable to use a formula of angelica root with additional Chai Hu and Qiang Huo. If there is stagnation of qi, add Mu Xiang; if there is bloating and pain in the heart and abdomen, add children's urine; if there is fullness beneath the heart and qi is not flowing smoothly, add Mu Xiang and Betel Nut. For external treatment, use hot tofu to cover the affected area; its warmth will promote steaming, and the flesh will turn purple; then cover it again with hot tofu until the purple flesh fades to a light red. This is also appropriate for purulent and decaying wounds. For severe cases, take internal herbal mixtures with myrrh to relieve pain, supplemented with as much hot wine as possible. If the patient is weak, after the sore has healed, it is essential to nourish qi and blood, as well as the spleen and stomach, along with swallowing Zi He Che Dan (a type of tonic), for the best recovery. Externally, apply yellow wax ointment and purslane ointment. If Zhang Chuang suddenly dries out and there is internal toxicity causing abdominal pain, confusion, nausea, and vomiting, it is difficult to treat.[13p]

    Xue's Medical Case Study

    Main Treatment Principles

    1. For hypochondriac and rib distension with pain, normal bowel movement, and coughing with phlegm, this indicates liver fire injuring the lungs. Use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction plus Qing Pi and Shan Zhi to clear it. If there is abdominal distension with pain, constipation, and coughing up blood, this indicates stagnant blood. Use Dang Gui Da Zhi San to relieve it. The "Inner Canon" states: the liver stores blood, and the spleen regulates blood. The liver belongs to wood, which generates fire that harms earth, leading to intense liver fire, which must injure liver blood and weaken spleen qi. First, clear the liver and nourish the blood to prevent stagnant blood from coagulating and tissues from breaking down. Next, strengthen the spleen and enhance digestion so that stagnant flesh can dissipate and new flesh can regenerate. If aggressive measures are taken, the weak will become weaker, and the stagnant will become more stagnant, leading to inevitable disaster.

    2. For abdominal pain, or constipation with severe pain upon pressure, this indicates internal stagnant blood. Use modified Cheng Qi Decoction to purge it. If the pain continues after purging and still hurts upon pressure, this indicates that stagnant blood has not been completely cleared. Use modified Si Wu Decoction to tonify and promote its movement. If abdominal pain does not hurt upon pressure, this indicates injury to blood and qi. Use Si Wu Decoction plus Ren Shen, Qi, and Bai Zhu to tonify and harmonize.[14p]
      If after a purge there is pain in the chest and sides, it suggests harm to the liver blood; use the Four Gentlemen, Chuanxiong, and Angelica to replenish. If after a purge there is fever, it indicates harm to the yin blood; use the Four Substances, Ginseng, and Atractylodes to replenish. If after a purge there is aversion to cold, it signifies harm to the yang energy; use the Complete Revitalizing Decoction to replenish. If after a purge there is aversion to cold and fever, it suggests damage to both qi and blood; use the Eight Treasures Decoction to replenish. If after a purge there is a desire to vomit, it indicates harm to the stomach qi; use the Six Gentlemen and Angelica to replenish. If after a purge there is diarrhea, it suggests harm to the spleen and kidney; use the Six Gentlemen, Meat Fruit, and Poria to replenish. If after a purge both hands and feet are cold, and there is fainting and sweating, it indicates deficiency of yang energy and cold; urgently use the Ginseng and Aconite Decoction. If there is vomiting and diarrhea with both hands and feet cold and blue nails, it indicates severe deficiency of spleen and kidney cold; urgently use a large dose of Ginseng and Aconite Decoction. If there is locked jaw, difficulty moving hands, involuntary urination, abundant phlegm, blue lips, and cold body, it indicates extreme deficiency with external signs; urgently administer a large dose of Ginseng and Aconite Decoction, many have been saved with this.[15p]
      When there is pain between the muscles, it indicates stagnation of the vital energy in the Ying and Wei; use the Recovery and Qi-Releasing Powder. When there is pain in the sinews and bones, it indicates damage to the liver and kidney energy; use the Six-Flavor Rehmannia Pill. If there is internal bleeding causing pain, it indicates deficiency of the spleen and stomach energy; use the Spleen-Boosting Qi-Tonifying Decoction. If there is external injury causing bleeding and pain, it indicates deficiency of the spleen and lung energy; use the Eight-Treasure Decoction. Generally, if there is persistent bleeding, it indicates collapse of the spleen and stomach energy. If there is vomiting and diarrhea without appetite, it indicates failure of the spleen and stomach energy. If one takes preventive measures to regulate and nourish the spleen and stomach, such issues will not occur.

    If the pain persists for four to five days without relief, or recurs after one or two days, becoming pustular, use the Suppressing and Expelling Toxin Powder. If pressing down on it causes it to swell again, and pus has formed, incision to drain the pus will relieve the pain. If headaches occur intermittently, it indicates deficiency of qi and blood; if the pain is accompanied by dizziness, it relates to phlegm. Hence, nourish the liver blood and replenish the spleen energy.

    If a swelling does not dissipate, use the Spleen-Boosting Qi-Tonifying Decoction to strengthen qi; if the swelling is dark and does not go away, use the Enhanced Relaxing Decoction to disperse blood. If there is heat, swelling, and pain, indicating stagnation of blood resulting in pus, use the Eight-Treasure Decoction with added Angelica to assist in drainage. If the pus has ruptured and there is subsequent pain, it indicates qi and blood deficiency; use the Ten-Complete Great Tonifying Decoction to replenish.[16p]
    If the bone reconnects but then dislocates again, it indicates liver and kidney deficiency, treated with Rehmannia Pill. If swelling does not subside and the color does not change, it suggests deficiency of qi and blood; internally use Eight Treasures Decoction and externally apply shallot poultices to disperse the blood stasis, gradually reducing swelling and pain. If blood flows and breaks, the spleen and stomach become more deficient, and the movement of qi becomes stagnated. If cool external medicines are applied, blood stasis worsens, internal decay deepens, leading to complicated issues.

    For a fever that arises from excessive bleeding or after pus drains, with a rapid and weak pulse that feels empty upon pressing, this indicates yin deficiency leading to fever; use Angelica Blood Supplement Decoction. If the pulse is deep and weak, it reflects an excess of yin leading to agitation; use Four Gentlemen with ginger and prepared Aconite. If fever and agitation arise with muscle twitching and tendons being tense, it signifies loss of blood; use Sheng Yu Decoction. If sweating is unceasing, leading to blood loss, use Alone Ginseng Decoction. If blood loss presents a strong pulse, while a restless pulse after sweating is difficult to treat, a thin and weak pulse is easier to manage.

    According to "Essentials from the Outer Chamber": when excess yin leads to agitation and one desires to sit in a well, use Aconite Four-Negative Decoction with shallot white. Wang Taifu states that any heat emerging and receding, appearing by day and hiding by night, and moving unpredictably is termed "rootless fire," indicating formless heat deficiency.

    For vomiting, if due to severe pain or due to obstructing factors that harm the stomach, use Four Gentlemen, Angelica, Pinellia, and ginger. If arising from anger harming the liver, use Xiao Chai Hu Decoction with Gardenia and Poria. If from phlegm-heat excess, use Er Chen Decoction with fried Coptis and Gardenia. If due to stomach qi deficiency, use Supplement Middle and Benefit Qi Decoction with fresh ginger and Pinellia.[17p]
    If there is excessive bleeding or due to abscess rupture, use Liu Jun Zi Decoction with Angelica.

    If there is wheezing and coughing, and if there is excessive bleeding accompanied by a black face, chest fullness, or chest pain causing wheezing, it indicates an accumulation of qi and blood in the lungs; urgently use Er Wei Shen Su Decoction. If there is coughing up blood or nosebleeds, it suggests qi rebellion and blood accumulation in the lungs; urgently use Shi Wei Shen Su Decoction with Gardenia, Scutellaria, Lian, and Chuanxiong.

    If there is thirst due to excessive bleeding, use Si Wu, Ren Shen, and Bai Zhu; if ineffective, use Ren Shen and Huang Qi to tonify qi, and Angelica and Shu Di to nourish blood. If due to abscess rupture, use Ba Zhen Decoction. If stomach heat injures body fluids, use Bamboo Leaf and Huang Qi Decoction. If the stomach is weak and fluids are insufficient, use Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. If stomach fire is excessive, use Bamboo Leaf and Gypsum Decoction.[18p]
    If there is thirst from heat, with scanty urination, it indicates虚 heat in the kidney meridian, which can only be remedied by the use of Dihuang Wan.

    If there is bleeding, whether it occurs from the affected area or orifices, it suggests an excess of liver fire and blood heat misdirecting, requiring the use of a modified Xiaoyao San to clear heat and nourish blood.

    If there is weakness of the middle energy, causing blood to improperly flow, use a modified Four Gentlemen Decoction or the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction.

    If the original energy has been depleted, failing to contain the blood, use a decoction of Ginseng with roasted ginger to restore yang; if there is no response, quickly add Aconite.

    If blood is congealed internally causing vomiting of blood, use the Four Substances Decoction with Chai Hu and Huang Qin.

    Generally, injuries, over-exertion, or anger leading to abdominal distension, may result from mistakenly taking harsh medicines like Dahuang, damaging the yang channels which leads to vomiting of blood, nosebleeds, or blood in the urine; while damage to the yin channels can result in blood accumulation and clots.

    If the muscles are dark and bluish, this indicates a deficiency in the spleen and lungs, causing loss of function in the channels; prompt replenishment of the spleen and lungs can still restore health.[19p]
    But if the patient does not understand this principle and does not use this method, it is a pity! When the hands and feet are injured and the vital energy is weak, whether due to excessive sexual activity, recklessly engaging in laborious tasks, leading to necrosis or non-painful festering, dark and unhealing conditions, one should greatly nourish the vital energy to preserve life. If the joints of the hands and feet are severed, it is not a concern. Bones may be broken, but tendons can reconnect, and there is no need to rush in cutting off; if it affects healthy flesh, then it is untreatable. If one takes preventative measures to supplement the spleen's energy, there will be no such issues. Generally, if there is internal festering pus or stagnation, one should use needles to disperse it from within. If there is jaw stiffness and difficulty urinating resembling tetanus, urgently use the Ten Complete Tonifying Decoction with added Aconite, and there are many who survive.

    If the necrotic flesh does not ulcerate, or is accompanied by chilliness without ulceration, use the Middle-Nourishing and Energy-Increasing Decoction; if there is fever without ulceration, use the Eight Treasures Decoction. If it does not ulcerate due to excessive repression, use the Six Gentlemen Decoction with added Angelica. If the outer skin is black and hard without ulceration, it is due to internal heat steaming; take the Eight Treasures Decoction internally and apply Angelica ointment externally. If the dead flesh cannot ulcerate, or if new flesh cannot grow leading to death, it is due to the failure to preemptively supplement the spleen and stomach.

    If new flesh cannot regenerate, and the afflicted area is pale, it indicates weak spleen energy; use the Six Gentlemen, Chuanxiong, and Angelica. If the afflicted area is bright red, it indicates deficient yin blood; use the Four Substances Decoction, Ginseng, and Atractylodes. If there is chill and fever, indicating Qi and blood deficiency, use the Ten Complete Tonifying Decoction. If the pus is thin and white and does not grow, it suggests deficiency in spleen and lung Qi; use the Middle-Nourishing and Energy-Increasing Decoction. If the pus and blood are red and do not grow, it indicates deficiency in heart and spleen blood; use Dongyuan Shengyu Decoction.[20p]
    When there is no response to cold and heat, it is due to liver fire movement; use a modified Xiaoyao San. If there is afternoon heat without response, it is due to liver blood deficiency; use the Eight Treasures Decoction and peony root. If there is little appetite and fatigue without response, it indicates spleen and stomach qi deficiency; use the Six Gentlemen Decoction. For purulent and filthy conditions without response, it signifies yin deficiency with pathogenic fire; use the Six Flavors Rehmannia Pill. If the limbs feel heavy and the spirit is lacking without response, this indicates inner injury to original qi; use the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction. In summertime, use the Diao Zhong Yi Qi Decoction; for diarrhea, use the Qing Shu Yi Qi Decoction. In autumn, for diarrhea use the Qing Zao Decoction.

    For severe injury with confusion, urgently administer the Single Ginseng Decoction; if there is internal stagnant blood, do not purge, but quickly use Huai Rui Stone Powder for internal transformation, fearing the loss of yin due to purging. If original qi is severely deficient, it is especially inappropriate to purge; continue to use the prior powder for transformation. In all cases of internal stagnant blood with constipation, use Da Huang and Qing Phragmites Crude; if blood has coagulated and does not descend, urgently use aromatic herbal powders like Mu Xiang and Rou Gui in warm wine to administer, so blood will descend and then vitality will arise. For weak individuals, use salts and yellow essence with Rou Gui and Mu Xiang, boiling together, exploiting its heat to disperse the cold.

    For severe constipation, if there is blood deficiency in the large intestine and excessive heat, use the Four Herbs Decoction to accompany Run Chang Wan, or use pig bile to guide it. If there is renal deficiency with dry heat, use the Six Flavors Rehmannia Pill. If there is qi deficiency in the intestines and stomach, use the Bu Zhong Yi Qi Decoction.

    For injuries that require the use of black sheep skin, it is because sheep's nature is hot and can supplement qi. If the injury from a blow is severe, and the flesh inside has decayed, apply it to promote ulceration; this will quickly lead to purulence.[21p]
    If there are no internal supplements to strengthen the foundation, toxic energy may invade internally; if there are no external methods to puncture and release the stagnant impurities, good flesh may still be harmed. If light punishment results in superficial skin hurt, it is best to apply Angelica ointment, along with the herbs Siwu, Qin, Lian, Chaihu, Shanzhi, Baizhu, and Fuling. Additionally, if scabs do not form, wounds do not fester, and dead blood disperses by itself, swelling and pain will ease naturally. However, if a comprehensive approach is taken to cover and apply everything, it fosters toxic stagnation.

    If after jumping, pounding the chest, twisting, lifting, or laboring there is chest and abdominal pain, and there is a desire to touch the hurt area, it is liver fire injuring the spleen, for which the formula of Four Gentlemen, Chaihu, and Shanzhi is used. If there is a fear of touch, indicating blood stagnation in the liver meridian, one should use Siwu, Chaihu, Shanzhi, Taoren, and Honghua. If there is pain in the chest and ribs, fever in the daytime, it indicates liver blood damage, for which the modified Xiao Yao San is used. If there’s pain in the chest and ribs with reduced appetite, it indicates injury to liver and spleen qi, so the Four Gentlemen, Xiong, Gui, Chai, Zhi, and Danpi should be taken. If there’s fullness in the chest and abdomen with diminished appetite, indicating stagnation of liver and spleen qi, one should use Six Gentlemen with added Chaihu, Xiong, and Gui. If there is no ease in the chest and abdomen, little appetite, and insomnia, indicating spleen qi stagnation, the modified Gui Pi Decoction should be used. If phlegm qi is stagnant, indicating stagnation of spleen and lung qi, one should use Erchen, Baizhu, Xiong, Gui, Zhi Zi, and Qingpi. If teeth gnash and convulsions occur, indicating strong liver and weak spleen, Xiao Chaihu Decoction, Chuanxiong, Shanzhi, Tianma, and Diaoteng must be used. Using windy medicinal herbs may further injure liver blood and exacerbate liver fire; drinking sugary liquor may additionally weaken kidney water, intensifying the liver fire.[22p]
    If you use drugs like rhubarb, it may harm the Yin channels internally and lead to bleeding. For the young and strong, this could result in chronic diseases, while the old and weak may suffer greatly.

    For a tetanus injury, Hejian states: Wind syndromes can change rapidly, and if they invade the organs, mortality can be imminent, so it is crucial to quickly discern the exterior and interior conditions to treat accordingly. If the pathogen is in the exterior, the sinews and vessels may become tense, occasionally alternating between cold and heat, with spasms in the muscles and a floating, wiry pulse; use Qianghuo and Fangfeng decoction to disperse it.

    If it's a condition that is half exterior and half interior, there may be slight sweating on the forehead but none on the body; treat with Qianghuo decoction. If it has penetrated to the interior, symptoms like a stiff tongue, locked jaw, tense neck and back, muscle spasms, excessive phlegm, a sensation of fullness and heaviness in the chest and abdomen, and difficulty urinating with crimson urine may present; in this case, there may be occasional sweating and a rapid, floating pulse, so use Daqinghuang decoction to guide it out. If there is already a bowel movement and sweating continues, the exterior is weak; therefore, use Baizhu and Fangfeng decoction to replenish it, and periodically administer gruel as well.[23p]
    What has been previously stated concerns the method of treating conditions where the qi is still empty but has not been damaged. If there is a large loss of pus and blood, with yang dispersing along with yin, resulting in both qi and blood being deficient, and the symptoms resemble those mentioned earlier, it is essential to greatly tonify the spleen and stomach, and completely avoid medicines that dispel wind.

    Regarding spasms, Zhongjing stated that all spasms with a stiff neck are due to dampness. He also mentioned that excessive sweating in the case of a taiyang disease can lead to spasms. In cases of wind diseases, purging can cause spasms to recur, and sweating can lead to a feeling of tightness. If a patient has sweated but does not feel cold, it is termed "soft spasms," as wind can disperse qi; the recommended treatment is Baizhu Decoction with added cassia twigs and astragalus. If there is no sweating but the patient feels cold, it is termed "hard spasms," as cold can congeal blood; the recommended treatment is Gegen Decoction. These conditions arise from internal injuries to blood and qi, where the tendons are not properly nourished, and are not caused by wind.

    For those with ulcerated wounds or injuries that lead to variations in qi and blood, it is necessary to tonify both blood and qi; the appropriate treatment is to use Dushen Decoction. If the hands and feet are cold, add cassia and asarum; if the condition is alleviated but not resolved, it requires further intervention.[24p]
    Principles of Diagnosis and Treatment

    General Discussion on Injuries

    The discussion on injuries states: Injuries must be traced back to their source, examining the severity of the condition and the depth of the damage. In a person's body, from head to toe, there are cuts, bruises, falls, and various injuries from sharp objects. Each of these injuries has its own explanations; for a physician, it is crucial to understand both the internal and external aspects before administering treatment. However, if a physician lacks understanding, they cannot be considered a competent healer. Some individuals may be naturally dull-witted, unable to assess the severity of symptoms or the depth of injuries, and may hastily administer treatments without proper understanding, causing great harm. This can lead to phlegm and fluids attacking upwards or cause obstructions in the internal organs, where a minor mistake can result in significant consequences. Thus, the saying goes: "A physician should not be trusted without careful prescribing; the treatment should not be taken lightly!" This serves as a fundamental guideline for treating injuries. While it is essential to apply the correct medications, it is even more critical to execute treatments with precision. The human body has a total of 365 joints, which are itemized as follows.

    List of Joints

    The human body consists of 365 joints, with the first 165 corresponding to significant connections; starting from the clavicle upwards and including the head, extending to the front and back, there are 49 corresponding connections, totaling 72. The top of the skull is referred to as the cranial bone, which varies in density, marrow, and moisture. Next, the cranial bone serves as the next layer, also varying in density and marrow.[25p]
    In the front of the skull, there is one bone that serves as the apex, slightly containing marrow. Women do not have this bone.

    At the back of the skull, there is one bone that serves as the cranial bone, possessing a gentle force and some marrow.

    At the back of the brain, there is one bone that serves as the occipital bone, possessing force but no liquid.

    Within the occipital bone, below it, there is one bone that serves as the celestial cover bone, which is the root of the lung system.

    Behind the celestial cover bone, there is one bone that serves as the celestial pillar bone, which connects to the vertebrae and contains marrow.

    In front of the celestial cover, there is one bone that serves as the speech bone, which connects to the skull above and has force but no marrow.

    Below the speech bone, there is the root bone of the tongue, with two on the left and right, having force but no marrow.

    In the front of the skull, there is one bone that serves as the hairline bone, which has no force or liquid.

    Below the hairline bone, there is one bone that serves as the subservient bone, often mistakenly referred to by common people as the sub-rhino bone; it has no force or marrow.

    Beneath the subservient bone, there is one bone that serves as the juncture bone, attached below the separation of the eyebrows, having no force or marrow.

    Above the left eyebrow, there is one bone that serves as the heavenly virtuous bone, having no force or marrow, and the same applies below.

    Above the right eyebrow, there is one bone that serves as the heavenly noble bone. Above the eyebrows are the eyes.

    Above the left eye, there is one bone that serves as the wisdom palace bone, having no force or marrow.

    Above the right eye, there is one bone that serves as the life gate bone. Below both eyes is the nose.

    In front of the nose, there is one bone that serves as the beam bone, which has no force or marrow.[26p]
    To the left of the beam is the zygomatic bone, one in position and without marrow, and the same applies below. To the right of the beam is the malar bone, one in position. Behind the zygomatic and malar is the division of the ear.

    At the end of the beam is the sternal bone, one without position or marrow. The left ear contains the zheng bone, one without position or marrow, and the same applies below. The right ear has the na xie bone, one in position.

    Behind the zheng and xie is the wan bone, two in total, without position or marrow. Above zheng and xie, attached inside, is the ti bone, one without position and with little fluid. Above the ti, the tong bone appears, totaling four from left to right and front to back, with position and a little fluid. Above ti is the maxillary bone, one without position and with much fluid.

    The maxilla connects posteriorly to form the jaw. The left jaw contains the cheng bone, one with position and much fluid, and the same applies below. The right jaw has the che bone, one in position.

    Behind the cheng and che is the yuan bone, two in total, with position and fluid. Above and below the cheng and che, there are thirty-six teeth, without position or marrow; if one is missing, the count is incomplete.

    Furthermore, below the yuan bone is the zheng zhong, extending from left to right, front to back until reaching the yow, containing forty characters and ninety-seven bones. To the left and right of the yuan bone are two ling bones, with much fluid. In the center of the ling is the hui yan bone, one without position or marrow.[27p]
    Under the bell, there are three bones related to the throat, including left, middle, and right, all without marrow. Below the throat, there are three bones related to the larynx, again all without marrow. Below the larynx, there are ten bones related to the pharynx.

    Inside the pharynx, there are twelve bones related to the lungs, all without solid marrow. Behind the lungs, there is one bone related to the valley, also without marrow. Below the valley, there are two bones related to the valley pathway.

    Outside the pharynx, below, there are eight bones related to the flow, with little fluid. At the end of the flow bone, there are eight bones related to the hidden flow.

    To the left below the flow, there is one bone related to the cave; women do not have this. To the right below the flow, there is one bone related to the shelf; women do not have this. Below the cave and shelf in the center, there is one bone related to the knee, without marrow. The common folk call it the dove's tail. Directly below the knee, there is one bone related to the heavenly pivot, without marrow.

    On the left and right below the bell, there are two bones related to the basin, with considerable fluid. In front of the left basin below, there is one bone related to the lower dislike, without marrow, similarly below. In front of the right basin below, there is one bone related to the meal separation, similarly below. Attached below the dislike and meal, there is one bone related to the granary.[28p]
    Below the chest, on both the left and right sides, are eight bones known as the "liao" bones, possessing strength but no fluid. To the left of the liao bones is one bone known as the "xiong" (chest) bone. If a man has a large this bone, he is valorous. To the right of the liao bones is one bone known as the "dang" (reckless) bone. If a woman has a large this bone, she loses her husband. Below the chest is one bone known as the "wu" (black) bone. If a man has a full this bone, his hair turns white early. Below the dang bone is one bone known as the "yi" (ventral) bone. This bone is high and often leads to delusions. Behind the bell-shaped structure are twenty-two "jiu" (spinal) bones, connecting up to the "tian zhu" (celestial pillar) and containing marrow. Below the jiu bones is one "da dong" (great movement) bone, connecting to the celestial pillar, totaling twenty-four vertebrae. At the end of the da dong bone is one "gui xia" (returning lower) bone, referred to by Taoists as the "tail gate." Behind the gui xia bone is one "cuan" (limit) bone, which can restrict semen. In front of the gui xia bone is one "you" (oat) bone. If this bone is thin, one often finds poverty. Furthermore, beneath the pelvic girdle, the left and right extend to support, comprising twenty-five characters that correspond to sixty bones. Below this, it divides into two arms extending to the tips of ten fingers. Behind the pelvic girdle is one "wu jia" (hunched) bone, with two sides, possessing strength and much fluid. At the end of the wu jia bone are two "jia yin" (hidden armor) bones. If this bone is long, one becomes virtuous. The front support of the pelvic girdle is the "fei dong" (flying movement) bone, with two sides. If this bone is short, it leads to illness. To the left of the fei dong bone is one "long nao" (dragon tibia) bone, possessing strength but lacking marrow or fluid, similar below. To the right of the fei dong bone is one "hu chong" (tiger冲) bone.[29p]
    Under the dragon's belly, there is one bone that is the essence of the dragon; under the tiger's belly, there is one bone that is the essence of the tiger, both having power and marrow. The base of the essence is the wrist. Above the dragon’s essence, there is one bone known as the advancement of worthiness. For men, this bone is prominent and represents esteemed ministers. Above the tiger's essence, there is one bone known as the attainment of rank. For women, this bone is elevated and represents virtuous wives.

    On the front left and right of the wrist, there are a total of eight bones related to strength, both having power and much fluid, categorized the same. The next layer of strength consists of ten bones called the resting bones, both sides counted the same. The layer of resting bones comprises ten bones called the gripping bones, both sides counted the same. Next to the gripping bones are ten bones called the assisting strength bones, both sides counted the same. To the left, the assistance is represented by claws, and to the right, by armor.

    Below the claws and armor, there are supporting bones, totaling ten, without power or fluid. Furthermore, the angle bones below, accounting for front and back to the initial step, represent one hundred thirty-six bones totaling fifty-one characters, from here down to the area beneath the breasts, branching left and right at the meeting of the bones in both feet. Below the angle, there is one bone known as the heart-covering bone, which has no marrow. To the left of the angle is the rib bone, with a total of twelve above and below, corresponding to the division of the small intestine. At the end of the left rib, there are supporting hidden rib bones, also ranked as twelve, without marrow. Beneath the rib bones, there are two seasonal rib bones, which contain more fluid.[30p]
    At the end of the season of Qi, there are two hidden bones associated with it, without marrow. To the right of the bones, there are twelve ribs, corresponding to the division of the sun. Below the ribs, there are two lesser ribs, each without hidden bones, which only beasts have. At the end of the right rib, there are twelve hidden ribs, without marrow. Before the iliac bone, there is one large transverse bone, with a slight quantity of marrow. Before the transverse bone, there are two white ring bones, each with strength and some fluid. Before the white rings, there are two inner support bones, left and right, each possessing strength and some fluid, as above. Behind the inner supports, there are two skeletal joint bones, left and right, as above. Below the skeletal joints, there are two lever bones, left and right.[31p]
    Below the femur bone, there are two pelvic bones on each side, with significant marrow. Below the pelvic bones are two patellae, with not much liquid. On each side of the patella, there are two fibulae, with significant liquid. Below the pelvic bones, there are two tibiae, with significant marrow. Outside the tibiae, there are two outer accessory bones, with significant presence of liquid, and the same applies below. Below the tibiae, there are two standing bones, one on each side. Each standing bone has two inner and outer ankle bones, totaling four, with little liquid. In front of the ankle bones, there are ten metatarsal bones, with significant liquid. Behind the ankle bones, there are two heel bones, with little liquid. In front of the metatarsal bones and in front of the talus, there are ten bones called "qipus," with significant presence. In front of the "qipus," there are ten supporting bones, with significant presence.[32p]
    Before the flat assistance, there were supporting bones, ten in total on both sides, without much potency or liquid. In the two sides of the explanation, there were core bones, two on both sides, with more potency and liquid. Below the starting servant, there were initial bones, two on both sides, with power but no marrow or liquid. Women lack these bones. In total, there are three hundred sixty-five bones. When heaven and earth interact, only humans possess the utmost spirit. Women, however, do not have the top authority. Apply blood dispersing ointment for wounds. If there are bruises or injuries without broken skin, use flesh capturing ointment for application. For cuts or injuries around the upper lip caused by knives or axes, use a small strip of silk to bind at the back of the head and bring it forward to stitch and set; then apply sealing medicine at the mouth, and externally use blood dispersing ointment. For realigning the lower lip, a silk strip should be tied under the chin and adjusted as done previously, then apply powdered medicine. If there is no swelling, no ointment is needed. If someone playfully bites down on a knife and accidentally damages the tongue, if not completely severed, use sealing medicine and change it two or three times a day, fully healing in seven to eight days.[33p]
    For injuries to the two salivary glands caused by cuts or blows, if the gland is opened, stitch it up with silk thread and apply a sealing medicine. Then, use a hemostatic ointment externally. In seven to eight days, if the flesh bonds, remove the stitches and apply the sealing medicine.

    For teeth struck, knocked, or broken, if a tooth is lost, only use a muscle-repair powder and the sealing medicine. Also, take blood-stopping and pain-relieving medicine, using decoction with water; it is not advisable to use wine for decoction. This method is known to be very effective.

    For broken teeth from blows or cuts, if the teeth are not displaced, use powdered hibiscus ointment. If the teeth are loose, grind the root of a thistle and use it as powder—apply it regularly to stabilize the teeth.

    For throat cuts, hold the patient's head with your foot, sew the internal throat with silk thread first, then sew the external skin of the neck, and apply sealing medicine externally, using hemostatic ointment to dress the wound and change the dressing. If the throat is bent from a blow, align it by hand and then apply ointment. However, if the throat injury is severe and the soft tissue is torn, it is untreatable. If the patient can ingest soup, cure is possible. If it comes out, it is incurable.[34p]
    In cases of injury to the neck, shoulder, and ribs from falling from a height: if the neck bone is dislocated, take a towel and a rope, tie them from the roof to hang down, and use the towel to secure under the chin, tying it at the back of the head. Tighten the knot, and place a five or six-inch tall jar underneath, adjusting the height for the patient to sit upright on it with their feet extended. The practitioner should carefully manipulate the alignment while speaking to keep the patient unaware, and then with a kick, knock the jar away. If it's on the left side, use the left hand to assist; if on the right, use the right hand. Apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relief ointment.

    Another method: have the patient lie on the bed while another person pressures their head, with both feet stepping on the shoulders to assist in repositioning.

    If the shoulder bones are dislocated, and the bone is sticking out in front, use a towel to bind the wrists at the chest; if protruding from the back, bind the wrists behind. If the left is out and tilts towards the right arm, push it in; if the right is out and tilts towards the left arm, do the same. Apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relief ointment to both sides.

    For injuries to the shoulder well and below the ribs, do not bind; simply apply pressure to realign them, using meat-repair ointment, bone-setting ointment, and pain-relief ointment for treatment. The same applies to the rib bones.[35p]
    Any time there is a dislocation of the shoulder bones, one should assess the condition and how to set it. Use a chair for the affected person to reach out with both hands into the left cavity, the right shelf, and the five basic bones, totaling three hundred sixty bones. Furthermore, there are one hundred ninety bones in men and women, some hidden, some supporting, and some lacking marrow; the remaining two hundred fifty-six bones have marrow fluid that is stored in the muscles, meeting the pulses and valleys, needed to form the body’s shape, referred to as the four greats. This is the standard for bone measurement.

    For injuries to the head, eyes, nose, or ears: If the cranial bones are fractured, apply light pressure to stabilize them. If the skin is intact, use anti-swelling ointment for application. If the skin is broken and flesh is damaged, first use a sealing medicine to treat it, then apply a hemostatic ointment outside. If there is bleeding, use a hemostatic powder to treat it. For swelling and pain, apply mashed kudzu leaves, hair vine leaves, or the tails of maple leaves, ensuring that they do not come in contact with wind or water, for fear of developing tetanus.

    Fractured cranial bones located at the temples can be treated. However, injuries at the temples themselves cannot be treated. If the injury is near the hairline, one must cut or shave the hair and check whether the skin is broken. Based on that, apply the appropriate medicine as previously described.[36p]
    If you wish to wash, it is appropriate to use cooked oil mixed with medicinal water, or wash with warm tea. For facial wounds that are bruised and dark, apply a purple powder, or adhere with a purple gold ointment. For more severe wounds, use a flesh-repairing ointment for application.

    For injuries at the corners of the head or the back of the neck, or on the eyebrows, they can be treated. If the eyes are injured and the pupils are intact, they can be treated. If the eyelids are bruised and dark, apply a purple powder, or a purple gold ointment. For severe cases, use a flesh-repairing ointment for application. If there is damage to the top of the head, it is difficult to treat.

    For injuries at the nostrils that are concave, they can be treated. Blood loss is not a concern. If the bridge of the nose is bruised and sunk from impact, use a flesh-repairing ointment. If the nostrils are affected and have opened wounds from a fall, or from cuts or blows, apply sealing medicine to the wound and use a blood-dispelling ointment on the outside to reduce swelling.

    For injuries to the ears from blows or falls, or if the upper part separates from the lower part or vice versa, use sealing medicine for internal treatment and a blood-dispelling ointment for external application. For ears that are detached, use a goose feather to hold them in place, and secure them with a bamboo clamp. When binding, ensure the ears are aligned and bind gently.[37p]
    In case of injuries to the tongue, lips, mouth, throat, teeth, and jaw: for cuts caused by blades, axes, or falls that break the skin and flesh, first sew the wound with mulberry bark thread, then apply sealing medicament. Next, use blood-stanching ointment for dressings, ensuring the sealing medicament remains intact and advising the patient to speak less.

    For injuries where the lip, ear, or nose are broken and missing, apply sealing medicament and outside of it, place blood-stanching ointment. If a part of the lip or ear is missing, first apply anesthetic, then use scissors to trim some outer skin, and sew with silk thread. For a missing ear, suture it in two sections; for a missing lip, suture in three sections. Apply egg yolk butter and then sprinkle a little golden dog hair on top, followed by more sealing medicament. The next day, gently wash with tea and apply sealing medicament again.

    Change the dressing once a day, and after eight days, cut the stitches and reapply sealing medicament.[38p]
    For injuries to the cheeks, jaw, or those caused by cuts and falls that break the skin, use sealing medicine to fill the wound, and apply a brace on the outside. Secure it with the hands, and use soft cloth to support underneath. Have one person hold it steady while two others stretch and reposition it. If it falls, bend the wrist again, stabilize it, and apply pain-relief and bone-setting ointments, then bind it with silk cloth.

    For hand injuries: there are four bones in the hand that can dislocate and six joints. In the case of a dislocated arm, the upper segment is the joint, and the lower segment is the handle. The tendons around may also be damaged, causing dislocation. This bone must be pulled straight; one person pulls while another holds the bone steady to guide it back in place. Observe which side the bone has moved to, and use a piece of bamboo to hold one side, leaving the other side free, focused on the bent and straight portions. After applying medicine, do not let it be stable; continue to adjust as needed. Because there are many tendons here, if it is not straightened after the medicine, it may lead to complications, making the hand unable to move properly later on.

    For dislocations at the shoulder: if the arm bone is dislocated downward, the body joint socket is dislocated upward, and it can occur on the left or right. Use a pestle and a low stool. Have the patient stand on the stool, using the pestle to push against the dislocated area. If lower, use something to lift it. If the pestle is long, adjust the stool. Have one person hold it steady, while another pulls the arm down from the stool, and another holds the pestle, guiding the patient to sit down to align the joint. This method is effective.[39p]
    If a small stool is not available, position two small ladders opposite each other. Insert a wooden stick through the legs of both ladders and hold the stick firmly in the middle. Let yourself fall from above onto the area where the bones dislocated under the armpit, and the joints will naturally return to their socket.

    For a dislocated wrist, straighten and pull out the bones. The physician should lift the wrist while stabilizing the patient's knee, applying pressure at the neck and shoulder to return the bones to their proper place. Then, apply pain-relieving ointment and bone-setting ointment. If the wrist is displaced, whether upwards or downwards, pull it gently, ensuring the hand is secured, and then apply the aforementioned ointment and bandage it.

    If the wrist bones are out, turn a round chair upside down and use your foot to hold the chair down. Adjust the patient's hand within the chair to align the wrist properly, using a small book to stabilize it. Then apply the ointment and wrap it in silk cloth, ensuring the palm faces upwards while binding. If the hand is dislocated, do not pull or extend it; instead, support it with clothing from below, gently shaking and adjusting it to realign. Lastly, apply the ointment and secure it with a brace, ensuring an additional lining is used below.[40p]
    Whenever a hand bone protrudes to the left, the physician should use the right hand to pull it back in; if the bone protrudes to the right, the physician should use the left hand. After extending and contracting, shaking it two or three times, apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relieving ointment, then bandage tightly.

    If only one side of the hands or feet is broken, it can be treated; however, if both hands and feet are broken, it cannot be treated. For broken hand or foot bones, bind them tightly in the middle, and allow the ends to be slightly looser to gather qi and blood at the break.

    If binding the hand, leave the front end looser to allow blood to disperse. If binding the foot, leave the lower end looser to allow qi and blood to disperse downwards.

    For a downward protrusion of the palm, turn the palm upward. The physician should manipulate the injured area, bending the palm outward to make it even, then apply ointment and bind it. For the back of the hand, a longer piece of cloth is placed on the outer back; for the palm, a shorter piece is placed at the pressing point. A longer piece is placed at the curve of the little finger; a shorter piece is placed at the bony part of the thumb, with three layers of binding.

    For broken bones in both arms, those with shattered bones can be distinguished from those broken without shattering. All can use pain-relieving ointment and bone-setting ointment for application.[41p]
    For injuries to the fingers caused by falls, cuts, or being struck by axes, apply chicken egg yolk oil, then sprinkle with sealing powder, and cover with a hemostatic ointment, securing it with a silk cloth. If there are bites or abrasions, use lamb's ear powder for dressing; if there are symptoms of cold or fever, use a fever-reducing powder for application, and the cold or fever will subside.

    For dislocated wrists, when the bones become interlocked or dislocated from the socket, it may be necessary to realign the bones back into place. If the bone is dislocated towards the outside, it must be pushed inward; if it has gone inward, it must be brought outward to return to the socket. Simply pulling with one's hands might result in a difficult reduction, leading to a chronic condition. It is advisable to use bone-setting ointment and pain-relieving ointment for application and binding. For fractured bones, use fir bark and bamboo strips for support; for dislocations, only use cloth for binding without clamps, and it is important to keep moving it regularly to avoid stiffness; prolonged immobility may hinder proper healing.

    For chest and side injuries: If there is a dislocated bone in the chest, the patient should rest on a firm surface. The physician should stand by and step on the patient's feet with their own, then reach under the patient's arm to cross over the back and embrace the patient's back. With one hand, lift the chest (specifically the bone at the chest) to allow it to return to place, and subsequently apply pain-relieving ointment and bone-setting ointment.[42p]
    Whenever there is a bruise or injury to the chest bones, with external swelling and internal pain, apply a pain-relieving ointment externally and use blood dispersing medicine internally to eliminate stagnant blood. Then, consume a decoction of blood-soothing herbs mixed with wine. For knife wounds, first stabilize the bones and align the skin, ensuring they are smooth and straight, then apply sealing ointment to close the wound. Externally, use a muscle-repairing powder mixed with egg whites for dressing, and internally take restorative and blood-activating medicines.

    For broken chest ligaments, first apply blood-dispersing medicine, then use pain-relieving ointment and bone-setting ointment for dressing. If there is a skin break, apply a flesh-repairing ointment.

    For severe injuries to the chest and sides where blood does not flow, use mung bean juice mixed with ginger for ingestion. It is advisable to have a strong person behind to compress and help expel the blood, followed by blood-dispersing medicine.

    If the abdomen is injured and the skin is torn, with the intestines protruding, it is difficult to treat if the intestines are completely severed; however, if they are torn but not completely cut, they can be treated.

    For protruding intestines, have the patient place their hand on the physician's shoulder and curl the intestines back in while applying sesame oil to lubricate the wound. Once returned to the abdomen, use a laxative powder to induce sneezing, allowing the intestines to retract naturally. Use mulberry bark thread to suture the inner skin, then apply sealing medicine to the wound, and externally use a muscle-repairing powder mixed with egg whites for dressing.[43p]
    If there is bleeding, a more excellent treatment is the application of blood-stopping powder. It should be applied with flower milk stone.

    For a stomach that has split open, use hemp thread for stitching, or use mulberry bark as thread, and also apply flower milk stone powder to the stitches. The internal stitching of the stomach should be done from the inside; do not stitch from the outside, leaving the outer skin open. Apply medicine and wait for the flesh to grow back.

    If there is a small perforation in the intestine, shine a light on it. If there is gas escaping from it, it cannot be treated.

    Another method: if the intestine is protruding, lift the patient’s hands, and have them swallow a mouthful or two of vinegar brewed with mountain bean root, then pierce a needle into the patient’s neck, and the intestine will retract by itself.

    For injuries with large openings in the stomach, where both the intestine and fatty tissue are protruding, if placed back inside, it should be stitched; if the opening is small and only the fat is out, use your hands to push the fat away without stitching. The protruding fat is already useless and should not be returned to the stomach as it would cause further harm; just push it aside without concern. This is known as seen flesh, and you can safely remove it.

    For internal injuries, focus on treating the small and large intestines specifically; do not delay, for it may lead to serious issues.[44p]
    Injuries to the waist, hips, thighs, and knees: Whenever the lumbar bones are fractured, place a piece of door on the ground, with one end elevated. Have the patient lie on it, extending their hands up to grasp the door, while three people pull and stretch from below. Apply pressure to the injured area for a prolonged period. Then use pain-relieving ointment and bone-setting ointment for application. If the patient moves their body throughout the night, by the next day the affected area should be pain-free, allowing them to turn freely; still, use the blood-stabilizing medicine.

    For dislocations of the hip joint, where the right bone protrudes into the left and vice versa, push the foot in, steadying and aligning it carefully, and apply medicine. If the injury is inward, have the patient cross their legs and press on their shoulders, while the doctor uses their knee to push in; even though there may be significant pain for a moment, it will not matter. Realign it properly and then apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relieving ointment. The patient should lie on their back and should not turn onto their side, as excessive movement may lead to further injury.

    For injuries to the waist and legs, use alcohol in combination with blood circulation medicines, and always add eucommia bark.

    For dislocation of the hip bone from the upper buttock, have two to three people hold the legs steady and pull to stretch, using their feet to support the person. Apply the aforementioned ointments. If the dislocation is deep within the groin area, it is difficult to treat.

    Injuries to the bones of the foot are very challenging to realign and will require careful assessment at the moment; it’s hard to make a definitive statement.[45p]
    For cases where both legs have suffered fractures, use manual techniques to realign the bones. Pull upwards seven parts in front and five parts in the back, then secure it in place. Apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relief ointment, and bind it. When binding, first secure the middle, then the top and bottom, using an external brace. If there is swelling and pain in the upper and lower parts, change the dressing only after five days.

    To distinguish between internal and external dislocations of the hip joint, if there is no swelling at the knee, it indicates an inward dislocation; push inwards from the inside to align properly. If the knee is stuck and cannot open, it indicates an outward dislocation; push inwards from the outside to align properly, adapting to the situation.

    For a dislocated ankle, have the patient sit comfortably. The practitioner should use their foot to press and shift the affected leg, while simultaneously gripping and shaking a couple of times. Then apply bone-setting ointment or injury ointment.

    For knee injuries, after applying pressure to realign, use ointment on the front and secure with mulberry bark as a four-point wrap. If the kneecap is dislocated, use a bamboo brace to stabilize it, applying medication and securing it in place. It's crucial to apply the four-point wrap; otherwise, the knee will not stabilize. If there is swelling and pain, a needle or knife may need to be used to release blood, followed by medication and binding.[46p]
    If there is an injury from falling on the ankle bones or from the left and right foot, it should be straightened and pulled back in place using the foot, then pressed flat and treated with a topical plaster. If the knee cap dislocates, do not pull it too straight or too bent. If pulled straight, the bony edges aren’t visible, and the same applies if bent. It should be held halfway straight and halfway bent, using a bamboo hoop to secure the knee cap and binding it with rope.

    For any fractures or dislocations of the joints, whether from falls affecting the arms, waist, or knees, one must use proper techniques to realign them. First, administer an anesthetic to eliminate pain, and only then can the hands be used to treat the injury.

    For foot injuries, there are six dislocations and four fractures. Whenever there is a dislocation at the junction on the sole of the foot, someone must pull it while the other person manually adjusts the joint. If a bone is protruding inward, it should be pulled outward gently; conversely, if it is protruding outward, it must be forcefully pulled back inward to return it to its proper position. Merely pulling without adjusting the joint will cause chronic issues. It is advisable to apply bone-setting ointment and pain relief plaster.

    For strapping: in the case of the four fractures, use proper and additional bindings; for the six dislocations, only fabric wraps are suitable, without binding.

    For knee dislocations, the treatment is similar to that of the arm or elbow dislocations. Whether the dislocation is inward or outward, only one side should be secured. This area has a large number of tendons and meridians, so it requires constant attention and care. It is advisable to apply bone-setting ointment and pain relief plaster while securing the joint.[47p]
    For a dislocated hip joint, the bones at this part of the body resemble a mortise, and the thigh root acts as a pestle. Whether it dislocates forward or backward, one person must hold the afflicted person's body, while another pulls the leg, using all their strength to push it back into place. If the dislocation is severe, a soft cotton rope can be used to bind and hang the leg upside down, and the bones can be adjusted from above. Once repositioned, a bone-setting ointment or pain-relieving ointment should be applied and secured.

    For injuries to the spine, if the vertebrae are misaligned, do not attempt to adjust them by hand. Instead, a soft rope should be used to suspend the feet and allow the body to hang straight down, allowing the bones to realign naturally. If the bones have not returned to position, do not use force to realign them. Once the bones are straight, apply either bone-setting ointment, pain-relieving ointment, or flesh-repairing ointment. Place a piece of mulberry bark on the medicine, followed by two or three pieces of cedar bark on top, and wrap them with a soft material to ensure they remain straight, applying the medicine properly.

    For smashed bones in the hands or feet, anesthetics should be administered, or an incision should be made with a knife. In severe cases, bone edges may be cut with scissors to prevent the flesh from rupturing. In cases of fractures, the broken pieces should be removed to avoid the complications of pus and bleeding.[48p]
    Then take large pieces of mulberry bark to apply meat-grafting ointment or pain-relief ointment on top of it, pressing it against the flesh and bones, ensuring there are no mistakes. Wash it every three days, and do not let it become foul. Use medicine to dress it. Furthermore, do not easily rely on the presence of medicine to cut, clip, or manipulate; careful examination is necessary, and actions should be taken only when required, with particular attention to detail. If there are injuries on the head, if it is broken, or if there are knife wounds or crushed bones, apply medicine and bind the area. During the binding process, it is essential to do so in a windless, secluded space, preventing drafts from reaching the wound, as this may lead to tetanus. Remember this well!

    For injuries to the scrotum or perineum: if the scrotum has been pulled off, apply egg yolk and spread thinly with fur from a golden-haired dog, followed by sealing with a medicinal powder, and lastly apply blood-stopping ointment. Externally, take decoction of middle leaf golden key and purple golden skin, while washing with water decocted with perilla leaves.
