If leek leaves are not available, scallion leaves may also suffice. Additionally, take medicine to promote urination.[49p]
    For women with leg bones protruding near the vagina, do not step in. Use a stool covered with cotton cloth, allowing the patient to lie on top. The physician should gently manipulate the patient’s leg with their hands, pressing down while holding the healthy leg, causing the leg bone to return. Then, apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relieving ointment for treatment.

    For injuries near the legs and groin, do not use medicinal herbs to promote blood flow; instead, apply ointments to avoid bleeding.

    For tendon and bone injuries: If tendons are severed or bones are fractured, first use your hands to locate the injury, aligning the tendons and bones properly. Apply bone-setting ointment, and secure it with appropriate binds. The primary binding should be made from cedar bark, larger than a finger, placed over the flesh with medicine applied. A secondary binding can be used, made from bamboo skin, also around the size of a finger, loosely applied.

    For fractures that are shattered or not completely broken, but with damaged skin and flesh, first use a muscle-replenishing powder to fill the wound, followed by blood-stopping ointment. If there is a bone fracture, use bone-setting ointment followed by binding. If the skin is broken and the bone is fractured, use muscle-replenishing ointment for treatment.

    For cases of bone fracture with skin rupture, do not use alcohol to prepare medicine.[50p]
    If there is damage with broken skin and flesh, you may mix children's urine into the wound medicine for internal use. If the bone is fractured but the skin is intact, use wine to decoct the medicinal herbs for treatment. For injuries without broken bones or flesh, use swelling ointment or pain-relief ointment.

    For cases where the skin is broken and the bone protrudes unevenly, pinch the skin around the area for about three points, and make a small incision with a sharp knife to push the bone back in. There is no need to cut the flesh, as it will rupture on its own, allowing the bone to be repositioned. After the bone is in place, apply a meat-repairing ointment around the wound and fill the wound opening with muscle-repairing powder. If the skin and flesh are intact, apply bone-setting ointment and pain-relief ointment.

    For fragmented bones, assess how aligned the area is. Generally, if a bone appears lower, the surrounding bones are uninjured; if it's higher, those bones will likely have suffered damage. In cases of fractured bones, ensure they are aligned properly, applying ointment and securing with splints to prevent movement, thus allowing the damaged area to stabilize.[51p]
    When joints are dislocated, one must gently rotate them repeatedly to avoid excessive strain.     When needing to pull or stretch, one should use soft, thin materials and gently extend. Close to the injury site, do not go too far out along the bone, but continue to pull and extend. Assess the orientation of each bone, as there are specific angles for pulling and extending.[52p]
    All techniques for compression and restraint must be swift and proper, with the skin and flesh held evenly. When pulling, one must also assess the ease or difficulty; sometimes three or four people are needed, and care should not be taken lightly.

    For broken tendons, use maple incense to chop the gold grass for juice, then apply it for dressing.

    For binding and medicating: Generally, for binding, it should last three days in spring, two in summer, three in autumn, and four in winter. The binding area should be soaked with medicinal water, washing off the old medicine carefully without disturbing the injured area. After washing, continue to use the previous ointment for binding. If binding is necessary, use soft-immersed cedar wood stripped of its coarse bark and bamboo strips that are trimmed of yellow, making pieces about the size of a finger. Use cedar bark as the primary clamp and bamboo strips as the secondary clamp, loosely arranging them around the area. Bind it three times with small ropes, adjusting the height and distance to ensure the circulation of qi and blood in the injured area, allowing for both tightness and looseness, as stated before. Change the dressing every two or three days, aiming for one month of binding. Then apply good restorative ointment, also with cedar bark holding the area firm. For older bones, do not clamp them. Place cedar bark directly on the flesh, medicine on top of the cedar bark, paper over the medicine, and bind it with bamboo strips over the paper.

    For swelling caused by blood, wash with hot medicinal water and then apply herbal poultices.[53p]

Remove and clean the old medicine piece by piece without delay to avoid blistering. Always prepare the new medicine beforehand for immediate application. This is a major principle; neglect can lead to severe complications, so remember this!

    For severe injuries that are initially numb and painless, one should stretch and adjust the affected area, or carefully cut the skin with a knife. Pain may not appear until two to three days later, so it is essential to balance qi and blood first.

If it returns to internal organs or ascends, it will be expelled through the mouth; if it returns to the middle, it will be discharged by the large intestine, and this should be used for urgent care.     For injuries caused by blows from knives or axes, resulting in broken skin and flesh with significant bleeding, and if there is dizziness, first use chuan danggui and chuan xiong boiled in water to take, then add white peony root, cooked rehmannia root, fringed gentian, fangfeng, schizonepeta, qianghuo, duhuo, and nanxing, boiled in water.     In all injury and damage remedies, frankincense and myrrh cannot be absent, as these herbs are especially effective in dispelling stagnant blood and alleviating pain. For cuts or injuries from falling or dislocations, initially do not use natural copper, but after a while, it can be used. For bone fractures, it is advisable to use it immediately. If there is no fracture or splintering, it should not be used. All remedies for damage should focus on their benefits. When using natural copper, it must be calcined with fire before taking. However, freshly heated copper contains fire toxins that mix with metal toxins and carry fragrant heat that, despite having the ability to aid bone healing, can be drier and harsher than blades, so caution is advised!

    For falls that result in internal bruising, there will be abdominal distension and pain, or fullness in the chest and sides; it is advisable to use blood-breaking drugs and heart-cleansing medicines to facilitate recovery naturally.     For injuries from metal blades due to high falls, causing skin and flesh damage with excessive bleeding, it is advisable to prioritize pain relief and nourishment, suggesting angelica blood-nourishing soup.     For injuries, the key is to replenish qi and blood, which common practitioners do not understand; they only seek immediate results and often use natural copper, fearing chronic ailments may develop.     When taking medicines for loss, one must avoid cold foods. Fish and beef are extremely cold and should be avoided altogether. If one eats beef, the pain will not subside. Also, avoid eating pork from sick pigs or sows; remember this well!

    For any loss, one may take herbal medicines, but they must come from a large bone and not a human mortuary. When combining sovereign and ministerial medicines, they should be prepared with warming and blood-qi-tonifying herbs together.

    If external applications are ineffective, internal medicine will also not be effective. When using herbal poultices, it is essential to pick fresh herbs on-site for efficacy. If herbal remedies are unavailable, you can use the monarch and minister herbs together in a binding preparation.

    When a common person drunkenly falls and hits the ground, experiencing pain in the shoulders and back, unable to bend or stretch, and conventional treatments fail, taking black bean wine for several days will help. The bean can dispel qi, indicating that the damage is slight.

    For small children who fall and hit a corner of a table, simply using ground radish seeds brewed and consumed will aid recovery, as it also helps with qi.

    Generally, when applying treatments, avoid using medicinal washes on the head, as this might lead to tetanus; for other areas, you may use cooked oil mixed with medicinal washes to fend off wind and alleviate pain. Avoid using salt to resolve issues. If there’s vomiting, add fresh ginger juice.

    The above methods are prescriptions specialized for specific cases, noting that every individual has variations in their condition and treatments should not be generalized. For instance, if treating someone with completely exhausted qi, giving them concentrated caowu wine while their qi is depleted, followed by suhexiang pills, and then a cool remedy, could result in severe harm for someone with weak qi. One must follow the methods of the Xue family, which are grounded in internal replenishment, and I recommend reviewing the sections on diagnosis and treatment later in this text; learners should proceed with caution!

    Ten conditions that do not respond to treatment include injuries from falls or being struck that affect the lungs; even if death does not occur immediately, survival is extremely difficult. Also, injuries beneath the left ribs that penetrate deeply within.[63p]
    Injuries that cause a half rupture of the intestines can be treated, but those that cause a complete rupture cannot be cured.

    For injuries to the lower abdomen, if the symptoms are numerous, and the pulse feels weak and heavy, treatment is not necessary.

    In elderly patients, if there is a fracture in the left thigh, or if there is damage to the internal organs due to impact, or if blood has been completely lost, medication is also unnecessary.

    Liu Zonghou stated: Injuries from being struck by a metallic edge arise not from qi movement but from external causes. When affected by tangible external objects, it is the blood, flesh, tendons, and bones that suffer, differing from conditions caused by the six excesses and seven emotions, which relate to disturbances in qi and blood. Thus, for injuries, the focus is solely on blood. It is essential to distinguish between cases of blood stasis and excessive blood loss.

    In cases of impact or falls, if the skin is not broken but there is internal damage, it will certainly involve blood stasis. If a metallic edge injures the skin leading to blood loss, the two conditions should not be treated in the same manner. For those with blood stasis, treatment should focus on removing it, while for those who have lost blood, treatment should combine replenishment with other measures.[64p]
    Moreover, upon examining the injuries, there are differences in severity, depth, and the amount of vital energy and blood circulating in the meridians. It is essential to first expel the stagnant blood, unblock the meridians, harmonize the blood, and alleviate pain. Then, one can adjust the vital energy, nourish the blood, and replenish the stomach energy; all of these will be effective.

    Recently, I observed that soldiers in the besieged city who were injured, regardless of whether the severity was in the head, face, hands, feet, chest, or back, were universally treated with powerful laxatives such as rhubarb. When rhubarb became scarce, some even resorted to using castor beans, believing it would help dispel toxins immediately; however, this often led to serious harm later. Even slight injuries to fingers were treated similarly with laxatives.

    Little did they know that rhubarb is only suitable for those with stagnant blood; for those who have lost too much blood and whose vital energy and stomach energy are weak, it should not be taken. Castor beans are very heated and toxic; they can only break down hardened masses and eliminate accumulation, making them particularly inappropriate for these ailments. Consequently, after administering laxatives, if the pulse becomes increasingly hard and strong, the physician, failing to recognize this change, mistakenly believes that stagnant blood has not been fully expelled and continues to treat it further, which could lead to the unfortunate loss of life. Can one be too cautious in this regard?[65p]
    Tetanus

    The wind is the beginning of all diseases. When the body is clear and pure, the pores close off; even with a strong and toxic wind, it cannot harm. If the wounds are unhealed, the defense and nourishment are weak, the muscles do not regenerate, and the wounds do not close, then the wind evil enters, causing the condition known as tetanus. There are also cases of internal sores with heat and stagnation, often covered with white scabs, where the wound openings are blocked, making it difficult for the qi to circulate. Thus, when the heat is intense and leads to wind, one must first observe the wound: if it is flat and without discharge, it indicates wind; if yellow fluid comes out from the edges, it indicates dampness; and if there are signs of convulsions, urgent treatment is required.

    Dong Yuan says: Tetanus connects the exterior and interior, differentiating between yin and yang, and should be treated in a manner similar to typhoid fever. People understand the need for external treatment but do not recognize the necessity for internal attack and harmonization. If the pulse is floating and weak, it's linked to the Taiyang (greater yang) stage, so sweating is appropriate. If the pulse is long and strong, it pertains to the Yangming (bright yang) stage, hence purging is advised. If the pulse is floating and thin, it relates to the Shaoyang (lesser yang) stage, which is half in the exterior and half in the interior, requiring harmonization. Understanding these three methods will ensure treatment is aligned with the disease. There has not been a case where one has applied the three yang treatments and failed to address the illness. It is merely stated that these methods are for the three yang and does not involve the three yin, as the wind evil is found in the three yang channels, making early treatment according to the methods beneficial for recovery.[66p]
    If one waits to transmit into the three yin, the symptoms are already critical. There may be abdominal fullness with spontaneous bowel movements, dry mouth and throat, a curled and shriveled tongue, all showing no signs of vitality; therefore, such cases are set aside and not discussed.

    For exterior resolution, use Qianghuo Fangfeng Decoction, Fangfeng Decoction, Jiuwèi Qianghuo Decoction, and Wugong Powder; for internal resolution afterwards, use Baizhu Fangfeng Decoction. For purging the interior, use Daqinghuang Decoction, Hongbiaowan, and Zuolong Pill; then follow with Xiao Qianghuo Decoction. For harmonizing and resolving, use Qianghuo Decoction, Diyi Fangfeng Powder, and Xiao Chaihu Decoction.

    With prolonged illness, qi and blood become gradually deficient, and evil qi enters the stomach; it is advisable to use Siwu Decoction with the addition of Fangfeng, Gaoben, and Baizhi in equal portions, grinding Xixin to half as coarse powder. Each dose is five qian, boiled in water and taken warm. If there is excessive wind medicine and spontaneous sweating, use Baizhu Huangqi Decoction. If there is excessive sweating that does not stop, with muscle spasms, use Baizhu Shengma Decoction. If there are persistent spasms, use Juanjie Decoction.

    For spasms in the back, use Qianghuo, Duhuo, Fangfeng, and Licorice; for spasms in the front, use Shengma, Baizhi, Duhuo, Fangfeng, and Licorice. For spasms on both sides, use Chaihu, Fangfeng, and Licorice; if on the right side, add Talcum.

    For persistent trembling and dropping of hands and feet, use Zhushajiaosan.[67p]
    There are four forms of incurable signs: First, the head and face appear dark blue or black; second, beads of sweat do not flow from the forehead; third, the eyes are small and bulging; fourth, sweat oozes from the body like oil but the pain is not in the wound area—this indicates injury to the meridians and also signifies death.

    For external treatment:

    When sores swell and form white scabs, along with chills and fever, urgently apply Yuzhen powder. Alternatively, peel and finely chew apricots, mix them with realgar and fine white flour as a poultice. [One method uses equal parts of apricot kernels and flour mixed with fresh spring water to create a paste for application.] Gradually reduce the swelling. If the waist and spine are arching, limbs are stiff, and jaws are locked tight, take one mouse (the head and tail), burn it to ash, grind finely, and mix with lard from a pig raised in the twelfth lunar month for application. If the jaw is tightly clenched and cannot open, dry one centipede, grind it into a fine powder, and apply it to the gums to elicit saliva and relieve the condition. In the case of rabies from a dog bite, regardless of the quantity of ginseng, burn it over mulberry wood until the smoke is exhausted, grind it into powder, apply it to the wound, and use fish glue to boil, melt, and seal it.[68p]
    Surgical Authenticity by Chen Shigong of the Ming Dynasty

    Falls and Impacts

    Falls can be classified into those that have or have not broken the skin, and there are differences between losing blood and suffering from bruising. For instance, if one falls from a height without breaking the skin, there will be bruised blood accumulating within the organs, causing the person to feel dazed and unresponsive, resulting in difficulty with urination. One should use Da Cheng Decoction to promote urination, and the person will regain consciousness. If they remain unresponsive, the Guo Shen Decoction can save them. For ordinary falls, directly using the Revitalizing Blood Decoction is sufficient. If there are injuries to bones and joints, with torn tendons and continuous blood flow, the Sheng San can stop the bleeding. Following that, one should apply the Huai Rui Shi powder externally. For severe cases such as breaks in bones and major tissue damage, specialized methods for setting bones and binding will be needed; details for these procedures are not yet specified.

    Wounds from Sharp Instruments

    Wounds from sharp instruments, or "golden wounds," occur when cut by a blade. Some may involve deeper injuries that affect muscles and sinews. If the skin is merely broken, apply Tao Hua Powder to stop the bleeding. If the tendons are severed, mix in Sheng Jin Dao Powder. If bleeding resumes after stopping, it is imperative to apply Yu Hong Ointment directly to the wound, as the ointment promotes healing. If there is a fracture of muscles or bones, the person's complexion will surely turn yellow; they must avoid wind and cold externally, and avoid cold foods internally to prevent complications. For those who have lost an excessive amount of blood, the Guo Shen Decoction and Ba Zhen Decoction are essential for recovery; there are no alternatives for these cases.[69p]
    Zhang Chuang (Wound from a Cane)

    Zhang Chuang refers to the affliction of good flesh being hurt, distinguished by whether it is already burst or not, akin to the difference between punishment and extreme torment. For already burst muscle, apply a cooling and pain-relieving ointment after the cane strike, and the swelling will dissipate. If not burst, and there is internal bruising, use a needle to release the congealed blood internally, followed by taking Da Cheng Decoction, which will facilitate recovery. If the wounded area has rotting and has already begun to pain, apply jade red ointment to it, which will naturally decompose and regenerate, leading to healing. When enduring a situation with humiliation or extreme suffering, it is advisable to preemptively take Iron Cloth Shirt Pill to safeguard one’s body and life.

    Bite Wounds

    Human bites are a concern, as they injure good flesh. However, teeth belong to the Yangming stomach and are distinct, containing excess organs, and tend to be hot and fiery when produced in the mouth. Ingesting food through biting thoroughly masticated and swallowing, as well as the toxicity from cooked food, all contribute to the injury, resulting in swelling, extraordinary pain, foul pus, and decay that pierces the heart, which indicates the toxicity from the teeth. After a bite, within a day, wash the wound with warm urine to cleanse the yellow bruising from the teeth, then apply to the bite hole a toad fat paste. Cover with a bandage, and as the pus begins to emerge, healing will gradually occur. If this method is not followed and swelling and severe pain arise, wash again with child urine to cleanse it. Use coarse paper dipped in sesame oil, ignite it to create smoke, and let it waft over the swollen painful area until it subsides, to alleviate the tooth toxicity. Also, insert a strip of toad fat into the wound, cover it, and monitor as the swelling decreases, while regularly applying jade red ointment to aid in the healing of the flesh and mouth. If there are additional complications, treat according to those specific symptoms.[70p]
    Tetanus

    Tetanus arises from wounds in the flesh, which are subsequently invaded by external wind that gradually penetrates the meridians and moves inward. The external symptoms include alternating cold and heat, clenched jaws, arched back, and foaming at the mouth; if it affects the yin, the body feels cool with spontaneous sweating, and the wound appears flat and sunken as before, as the poison has internalized.

    One should use the Universal Elixir to induce sweating and expel the wind pathogen; then apply the Jade True Powder to the affected area, achieving effectiveness once pus is produced. If after sweating the initial symptoms do not recede, the wound remains flat, and there are periods of consciousness and unconsciousness, with intermittent spasms and inability to open the mouth or produce sound, it ultimately leads to death.

    From the Complete Canon of Medicine, Volume 378.[71p]

    Godly Efficacy Angelica Ointment

    It treats sores and poison from injuries caused by sticks, regardless of whether they have already burst or not. If the flesh is injured but not rotten, using this remedy will lead to self-healing. If the flesh is dead and you use it, it will cause the necrotic flesh to decay, allowing new flesh to grow easily. When the flesh gradually turns white, the poison is nearly exhausted, and new tissue forms rapidly. For injuries from sticks where the outer skin is intact but the inner flesh is rotting, the outer skin may dry out and harden due to internal heat, causing painful connections to healthy flesh, hence the common term "boil scab skin." Pus accumulates with no way to drain, leading to internal swelling and pain, and sometimes it becomes so deep that surgical intervention is needed before it ruptures, creating an opening that is hard to close.

    Weak individuals often develop tetanus from such injuries, frequently resulting in severe consequences. If there is stagnant blood within the stick wound, use a sharp magnetic piece to draw out the bad blood at the affected area, and apply this ointment. The boil scab will form naturally, dead flesh will decay, pus will exit, and what bursts will be superficial, allowing new flesh to grow without forming scabs and avoiding the pain of skin peeling, demonstrating remarkable efficacy.

    The ingredients, Angelica, Rehmannia, sesame oil, and two types of wax, are primarily for promoting flesh growth, stopping pain, nourishing blood, and reinvigorating tendons, which are all suitable for the flesh. This formula has already been published and is widely used by practitioners.

    Ingredients:

    • 6 taels of sesame oil
    • 1 tael each of Angelica, yellow wax, and raw Rehmannia

    Preparation: First, fry Angelica and Rehmannia in oil until dark, strain out the residue, melt in the wax, wait for it to cool, and stir evenly until the ointment is formed. White wax is particularly excellent.[82p]
    Tu Li San: For treating metal wounds, blunt injuries, and all kinds of sores and toxins caused by Qi and blood deficiency that fail to form pus; or when pus forms but cannot be discharged, presenting as thin, clear pus that does not heal over time.

    Ingredients:

    The internal dissolving formula treats injuries from strikes and blows, as well as all swellings and abscesses that have not yet burst, and can help them dissolve internally.

    In the past, when Xu Yuangong entered the capital for the provincial examination, he fell from his horse while crossing a bridge, suffering a dislocation in his right shoulder. Bystanders told his servant: "Quickly put it back in the socket; if blood stains the socket, it will be hard to treat." The servant followed this advice as Xu was unconscious and unaware of the pain, and they then hired a sedan chair to return to their residence.

    Some said that without the horse ridden to record the matter, he could not heal this injury. Urgently calling, he arrived just at dusk, and by candlelight he looked at Xu's face, which was still treatable. He then applied the medicine to seal the area, and by midnight Xu regained consciousness, and by dawn the pain had stopped. Upon removing the seal, the damaged area had turned white, and the bruising had shifted to the socket. From then on, daily adjustments were made, with the swelling extending to the shoulder and back. The medicine was applied, causing three liters of dark blood to be drawn, and within five days, he returned to normal, thus he was able to attend the examination; this was indeed the method used.[94p]

    Gao for Treating Injuries
    This remedy is for treating injuries from blows, fractures, dislocations, and injuries from knives, axes, and falls.

    Ingredients:

    • 4 ounces of Myrrh
    • 4 ounces of Natural Copper
    • 4 ounces of Yellow Wax
    • 4 ounces of Pig Fat
    • 1 ounce of Frankincense
    • 1 ounce of Myrrh
    • 1 pound of Rosin
    • 1 pound of Sesame Oil

    Preparation:
    First, take 1 ounce of the bark from broken wood, chop it finely, and cook it in the oil until boiling. Strain out the residues, then add the Myrrh and Yellow Wax, and simmer on low heat to create an ointment. Next, add the Rosin, melt it down, and continue simmering until it can form beads in water. Finally, incorporate the powdered Frankincense, Myrrh, and Natural Copper, mix well, and apply.[114p]

A small amount of pangolin fire powder. Grind everything into a fine powder, and take a 3-gram dose. If the condition is severe, take 6 grams mixed with good wine. For upper injuries, take it after meals; for lower injuries, take it before meals.[120p]
    Magnetic Stone Powder: For treating abdominal wounds with excessive bleeding, it is advisable to use this.

    Ingredients:

    • Talc, powdered: 3 liang
    • Iron essence: 3 liang

    Preparation: Mix these into a fine powder. Take one qian with a spoon, mixed with warm wine, and consume on an empty stomach at noon and in the evening. Additionally, apply needle sand on the abdomen to help it retract. One variation uses white rice drink for ingestion, while another omits iron essence.

    Puhuang San

    Used for treating bleeding from golden wounds and abdominal swelling that may lead to death.

Take 3 qian with empty stomach, mixed with wine, three to four times a day, until the blood transforms into water and passes.     Shenxian Zhi Xue San

    Used for stopping bleeding.
    Longgu, 1 liang (dried under tight conditions); Hezi (with the pit removed), 1 liang; Baishizhi, 0.5 liang; and Mumuye (harvested at noon on May 5 and dried in the shade), 0.5 liang. Grind these into a fine powder. Take 1.5 qian when not near food, mixed with water. During periods of union, avoid women and the sight of chickens and dogs.

    Bainu Jin San

    Used for injuries caused by golden blades and crossbows where the tendons cannot stretch or bend.
    Burnt Bainu Jin, Qin Jiao, and Duzhong (roasted), each 0.5 liang; Fuzhi (processed, skin and navel removed), and Danggui (cut and roasted), each 1 liang; Dazao, 3 pieces, take the flesh and roast. Grind these into a fine powder. Take 2 qian with warm wine, three times: on an empty stomach, at noon, and before bed. In one formulation, Xuduan is included without the jujubes.[122p]
    Sheng Gan Di Huang San: Used to treat restlessness from gold sores. Contains Sheng Gan Di Huang, Chuan Gui (stir-fried), Tao Ren (peeled, double kernels), Bai Zhi, Xu Duan, Huang Qin, Chi Shao Yao, Ling Yang Jiao (horn shavings), and Zhi Gan Cao, each one liang; Xiong (Xiang) and Gui Xin each three fen.     Bai Wei San: Treats restlessness and insomnia from gold sores, along with pain.     Hu Gu San: Treats gold sores with wind stroke causing spasms, stiffness in limbs and joints. Contains Hu Jing Gu, Bai Gui Ban (both roasted), Dang Gui, Gan Xie (lightly stir-fried), Tao Ren (peeled, double kernels, stir-fried), and Xiong each one liang; Gui three fen; Hei Dou five he; Song Zhi two liang. First roast the pine resin and black beans until cooked, then mix all ingredients and grind into a powder. Take two qian as needed with warm wine.[123p]
    Yong Tie Gao 【From "Bao Jian"】
    Take all types of needles and insert them into the flesh, like an arrowhead piercing the skin.
    One mouse head, or fry it in oil; forty-nine mole crickets; ten soil-dwelling insects; yanqing; ba dou; roasted horse meat maggots; roasted sauce maggots; letter; summer withering grass; naosha; magnet; yellow dan; earth bone peel; lignum vitae; and one tael of each type of dung beetle. Three taels of naphtha; three sheng of mugwort ash juice.
    First, combine the naphtha and mugwort ash juice and boil them down with even heat, then add the ground earth bone peel and other powders until mixed uniformly. Store in a ceramic container for temporary use. Apply medication according to the size of the wound, and after a while, the arrowhead will naturally push out.
    Xiong Huang San
    For treating drug poison that has entered the body from an arrowhead.
    One part realgar and half a tael of powdered frost, finely ground; four dung beetles ground into powder; three ba dou seeds with the skin removed, separately ground into paste.
    Combine these by grinding together, and using the tip of a copper chopstick, apply the milk to the wound. Use frequently, and after seven days, the wound will be matured, and the arrowhead will push out.
    Hong San Zi
    For application on gold wounds.

    Mix these into a fine powder, and with good wine, adjust to a paste. Apply this mixture to the wound, and the arrowhead will come out naturally.[124p]

    For treating gold wounds with arrow points stuck in the bone for many years:

    Arrowhead Removal Method

    • Ten dead scarab beetles
    • Three dogroots
    • A small amount of gray hair from a woman

    Remove the shells from the scarab beetles, take the white flesh and grind it with the two ingredients into a paste. Apply the paste directly to the arrow entry point like an ointment. After application, slight itching will occur; press with both hands, and the arrowhead will emerge on its own.

    Spirit Ointment
    Treats sores from rods and golden sores, injuries from falls, skin tears, scalds, and long-standing ulcers.
    Ingredients:

    • 3 taels of Chuan yujin
    • 2 taels of Sheng dihuang
    • 1 jin of lard from old pig
    • 1 tael of pulverized grass

    Prepare by finely grinding the ingredients, simmering in the lard until darkened, filtering out the residue, and mixing in 4 taels of bright yellow wax until melted and evenly blended. Store in a ceramic container, soak in water for a long time, then remove the water to collect the ointment. When using, first wash the wound with cold water and dry it, apply the ointment to the wound, and cover it with white paper to stop bleeding and ease pain, without leaving scars. For scalds and burns, washing with water is unnecessary. Particularly effective for frostbite.

    Frankincense Ointment
    Highly effective for golden wounds and rod sores.
    Ingredients:

    • 7 qian each of frankincense, myrrh, Chuan qiong, and natural copper
    • 5 qian each of dang gui, qiang huo, du huo, Chuan niu xi, gypsum, liu ji nu, huang dan, black qian niu, huang bo pi, old paper, white jiao xiang, sheng dihuang, shu dihuang, chi shao, bai shao, zi jin pi, and bai zhi
    • 1 tael of yellow wax
    • 4 taels of clear oil

    Except for the jiao xiang, dan, and wax, grind the remaining herbs into fine powder and simmer in the oil, stirring continuously with a willow branch. Test for paste consistency, then add the three aforementioned ingredients, testing again until it forms a paste. Filter with fresh cloth, place in a container with water, and spread with a comb over wound openings. For deeper wounds, twist into paste strips and insert into the openings. Regardless of depth, place on the wound. If treating heat-related sores, add light powder, fragment of brain, and (shí bǔ) salt into the paste before applying.[129p]
    Silver Powder Ointment: Treats ulcerations from walking sticks.

    Red Ointment: Treats ulcerations from walking sticks and sores.

    White Ointment: Treats ulcerations from walking sticks and sores.[130p]
    To prepare this medicine, take the following ingredients: one qian each of calcined water from Gan Stone, calcined white wax, dragon bone, frankincense, myrrh, balsam, camphor, and mercury; two liang of powdered light; one fen each of musk and powdered brain; half a liang of yellow wax; one liang of cypress wax; and one and a half liang of lard.

    First, melt the wax, then add the oil, mix well, and let it cool. Combine with the powder, mixing thoroughly, and spread on oil paper for use. For treating sores, apply as a plaster.

    The black plaster is effective for treating sores from injuries and various other wounds.

    Gather two liang each of coriander, yellow flower garden, cypress leaves, mint, and pig's eye; five qian each of wood frog, white atractylodes, apricot kernel, peach kernel, and fresh rehmannia; one liang each of protective wind, schizonepeta, forsythia, rhubarb, coptis, scutellaria, and phellodendron; one liang each of angelica, red peony, root of bellflower, frankincense, myrrh, catechu, rhubarb, and angelica; five qian each of cedar charcoal skin, balsam, calcined dragon bone, calcined stone wax, blood-resin, and camphor; two and a half qian each of calcined child's bone, mercuric sulfide; and five fen of musk.

    Prepare the last fifteen ingredients first, chop the first twenty-one into pieces, and simmer with water to reduce into a thick syrup. Filter out the residue and simmer again until the syrup has the consistency of syrup; then add two jin of lard and slowly cook until it dries. Next, mix in one jin of powdered light, stirring until black and forming a paste that can be rolled into beads when dropped into water, without sticking to hands. Finally, add two liang of yellow wax, melt it, and let it expel the toxicity over a few days. Briefly roast, then mix in the powdered frankincense and the last fifteen ingredients, stirring evenly, and spread on oil paper for application.[131p]
    Secret Salve: Specially cures injuries, treats deep wounds and unnamed swellings, as well as ulcers. It is not suitable for bruises and other types of sores.

    Use four ounces of true fragrant oil. First, simmer a piece of pangolin and a sprig of cypress in the oil until boiling several times. Remove the residue and, while hot, filter the oil through thin cotton. Return it to the pot and bring it to a boil, then add the following ingredients sequentially.

    In winter, use five ounces of oil, one piece of pangolin, and one sprig of cypress. For these two ingredients, only the oil infusion is needed, without the residue. Prepare a branch of locust, cut into small strips, not from a large tree. Add to the medicated oil and stir frequently.

    Using pure water, take one ounce of fine powder from “Fei Dan” (a medicinal product). Prepare this in two batches with fine powder that has been dried and sifted.

    For the preparation:

    • Three coins each of blood resin, myrrh, frankincense, and child tea, crushed and mixed together, roasted until fine in a copper pot over charcoal fire.

    New pearls and new red ivory should be baked until stable, then ground into fine powder; old ones are not used.

    One coin each of flour (burnt to yellow) and finger nails (frying them until brown), ground into fine powder.

    For “Shi Ru” (a type of medicinal stone), roast in a copper pot and grind into fine powder.

    Three coins of fine powder each of Coptis and Scutellaria, and five coins of sea cucumber, as well as ten larger pieces of Pinellia, ground into fine powder.[132p]
    The above sixteen items should be thoroughly sifted, blended evenly, and divided into five portions, keeping one portion aside. Observe the quality of the medicinal plaster and adjust the amounts. Use only four portions for the preparation, following the steps below:

    For the ingredients:

    • Camphor powder: 4 qians
    • Yellow wax: 2 qians
    • Borneol: 1 fen
    • Musk: 3 fens
    • Asafoetida chunks: 5 fens

    After combining the four ingredients, add them to the pot just before removing it from the heat. Stir thoroughly, and then remove the asafoetida residue.

    Now, take the fine powder and divide it into five portions. Gradually add four portions to the pot as described. Keep one portion to adjust the thickness of the medicine as needed. If the four portions have been added and the mixture is still thin, gradually add this remaining portion. If the consistency is just right, set this one portion aside to mix into the plaster when applying it to the affected area, which is particularly effective.

    For cooking: Use 4 liang of high-quality fragrant oil, place it in a copper pot, and heat over charcoal until boiling. When boiling, add a twig of cypress and a piece of pangolin shell, and boil several times before removing the two residues.[133p]
    Take a piece of thin rice paper, heat it to filter the oil, and clean the pot. Reintroduce the oil into the pot and bring it to a boil. Add five qian of red powder, and stir rapidly with a locust branch, continuing until it forms a paste. After six or seven boils, rinse your mouth with clear water and spray a little water into the pot, then take the pot off the heat. When lifting the pot, take one part of finely powdered medicine from the front four parts and gradually add it while stirring vigorously as before. When this portion is finished, achieve an even mixture. Dip the locust branch in the medicine and let drops form, but not yet as beads; return it to the heat and stir vigorously until it boils again.

    For the second addition, gradually add one portion of the powdered medicine to the pot and stir as before. When it reaches an even mixture, let drops form into beads and return it to the charcoal heat, stirring until it boils.

    For the third addition, gradually add the medicine and stir as before until evenly mixed. When the drops form beads, they should still be sticky; return to the fire as before.

    For the fourth addition, gradually add the medicine while stirring urgently until well mixed. When drops form beads, they should almost be non-sticky; return the pot to the charcoal fire and wait for it to boil again.

    For the fifth addition, add two qian of yellow wax and five qian of red powder, stirring urgently as before until the drops form beads that do not stick to your hands but are not too old.[134p]
    If it still sticks to the hand, leave a bit of the powder to gradually fall, adjusting until it no longer sticks. When it is no longer sticky, add two qian of water, then four qian of camphor powder, stirring quickly. Then add three fen of musk, five fen of asafœtida, and one fen of borneol, stirring quickly until it’s well mixed. Remove the asafœtida residue, place the medicine in a ceramic vessel, and immerse it in cold water for a while to wait for it to solidify. Once it solidifies, expose the medicine to the sun in a clean place, dig a pit, invert the ceramic vessel into the pit, cover it with soil, and wait seven days before removing it.

    For preservation, use oil paper and bamboo leaves to tightly seal the bottle opening to prevent gas leakage. When applying the plaster, use hot soup to cook it, place clean oil paper on it, and do not heat the medicine directly; just place it in a warm container. Lay the oil paper on the container, spread the medicine on top, ensuring it is not too thick; it should be thin enough to see the paper underneath.

    If using silk for application, dissolve the medicine in hot soup and apply it on top. When applying, first simmer radish juice and mulberry leaves to prepare a wash, and let it steep overnight. Use this to wash the affected area before applying the plaster.

    After application, wash the area every day without changing the plaster. After two to three days, when blood disperses and wind is eliminated, replace it with the black plaster for wound closure, which is the ultimate remedy.[135p]
    Wan Ying Oil is specifically effective for healing ulcers with remarkable results.

    Prepare 2 pounds of true fragrant oil, filter it clean. Take 5 taels each of Huanglian, Huangbo, and Huangqin, and a bundle each of cypress and locust branches. Grind these thoroughly. Use 1 pound of red reshin, reduce it with water, dry it in the sun. For the gum resin, myrrh, dragon’s blood, and child tea, take 3 qian each. The four items mentioned should be pounded into powder and mixed, then add to a pot and fry over charcoal until boiling. Use elephant hide ash, fried with sand to remove impurities.

    Take 5 fen each of hai piao xiao and 1 qian of ban xia, and 5 fen of long gu. Grind these eight ingredients into a very fine powder, sieve through a fine mesh until well blended. Gradually add the following ingredients: 5 fen of asafetida.

    Next, take 2 pounds of true fragrant oil, filter it clean again, and put it in a copper pot to boil. Add Huanglian, Huangbo, Huangqin, and locust branches, boil for three to four times, then use fine summer cloth and thin silk paper to filter out the dregs; clean the copper pot, put the oil back in to boil, then add the previously prepared red reshin. Stir rapidly with locust branches until it drips into beads. While hot, transfer to a ceramic container, then gradually add the eight finely powdered herbs and asafetida, stirring vigorously until evenly mixed; remove the asafetida dregs. Allow to cool and after seven days, it can be used. Store and spread as described above.[136p]
    Iron Cloth Shirt Pill [from "Authentic Recipe"]

    This medicine, when taken in advance, allows one to endure torture without pain and also protects life.

    Lily Powder: Treats injuries from trauma, where deteriorated blood flows into the stomach, causing vomiting of black blood. Ingredients include chuanxiong, red peony, angelica, lily, fresh rehmannia, jingjie, tetradium leaves, rhinoceros horn, huangqin, huanglian, peony root, gardenia, curcuma, and rhubarb. Prepare by boiling with water and mix with children's urine for consumption. If it causes significant bowel movements, exclude rhubarb.[139p]
    Ying Tong Pill: Treats pain in the hands and feet after fractures and injuries due to the invasion of the four qi. Use half a pound of each: broken old paper, bone-setting herb (with hair removed), and Cang Zhu (Atractylodes). Roast half a pound of Chuan Wu (Aconite) mixed with the others. Fry the roasted items with mulberry wood ash until they expand. Alternatively, use six taels of roasted star anise on the ship. Exclude half a pound of Chuan Wu, and add one pound of fresh ginger, pounded finely, then mix with Chuan Wu and soak for two nights. Dry it to a powder and form pills the size of the Chinese parasol tree. Take fifty pills each time, using wine or rice soup as a chaser. Avoid hot foods during this time.

    Ru Xiang San: Treats injuries causing unbearable pain in the hands and feet. Grind separately three qian each of Ru Xiang (Frankincense) and Mo Yao (Myrrh), two qian of Bai Zhi (Angelica Dahurica), and five qian each of Rou Gui (Cinnamon), Bai Zhu (Atractylodes), Chuan Xiong (Szechuan Lovage), and Fu Ling (Poria). Grind these to a fine powder and mix well. Take two qian each time, without restriction on timing, mixed with wine.

    Qiang Huo Fang Feng Decoction: Treats the initial stages of tetanus when the evil is still on the surface. Urgently take this medicine to dispel it; if delayed, the evil will enter within and not harmonize with the medicine. Use four taels each of Qiang Huo (Notopterygium), Fang Feng (Saposhnikovia), Gan Cao (Licorice), Chuan Xiong, and dried roots of Dang Gui (Angelica Sinensis), and Shao Yao (Peony). Use two taels of Di Yu (Sanguisorba) and Xi Xin (Asarum). Take five qian each time, boiled in water.

    Fang Feng Decoction: Treats tetanus when the surface symptoms have not entered inward. Urgent to take. Use equal parts of Fang Feng, Qiang Huo (Notopterygium), and Du Huo (Angelica Dhurica). Take five qian each time, boiled in water, and combine with Wu Gong San (centipede powder) for significant effect.

    Wu Gong San: Use a pair of centipedes and three qian of fish bladders.[140p]
    The right is a fine powder, taken with Fangfeng decoction.

    Qianghuo Decoction treats tetanus, used when the condition is half exterior and half interior; urgently take this decoction to slightly alleviate the evil entering within, but it should not be used if not suitable. Ingredients include Qianghuo, Chrysanthemum, Ephedra, Chuanxiong, Gypsum, Fangfeng, Fritillaria, Huangqin, Xixin, Licorice, Zhiqiao, Bai fuling, and Mianjingzi, each one liang; also, Mint and Bai zhi, each five qian.     Diyu Fangfeng Powder treats wind in both the exterior and interior, with slight sweating of the head but none on the body; do not induce sweating, additionally treating both exterior and interior. Ingredients include Diyu, Fangfeng, Didingcao, and Maçi xian, each in equal parts. The right is a fine powder, take three qian each time, mixed with rice soup.

    Daqianghuang Decoction treats wind in the interior and is appropriate for dispersing it; urgently take this decoction. Ingredients include Chuanxiong, Qianghuo, Huangqin, and Dahuang, each one liang. The right is fifty to seventy qian, decocted with warm water for consumption, to harmonize the organs.

The right is taken five to seven qian each time, decocted with water. It can be taken if the organs are harmonious and there is spontaneous sweating. If the organs are blocked and urination is red, it is advisable to use Daqianghuang Decoction for treatment.

    Baizhu Decoction treats tetanus with persistent sweating, muscle spasms, and cramping. Ingredients include Baizhu, Gegen, Shengma, Huangqin, and Shaoyao, each two liang, and Licorice two qian and five fen. The right is taken five qian each time, decocted with water, without a specific time for consumption.[141p]
    Qianfu Zhu Sha Wan treats tetanus, with symptoms including wide-eyed gaze, inability to speak or move limbs, neck stiffness, and lack of recognition of people.

    Ingredients: Zhu Sha, Ban Xia (washed), Chuan Wu (each one tael), Xiong Huang (five qian), Feng Huang Tai (three qian), and a pinch of Musk. Grind the ingredients to a powder, shape into jujube-sized pills, and take one or two with cold water to induce vomiting as needed. If not vomited, add one more pill. If unable to stop vomiting, take scallion white soup to halt it; sweating indicates effectiveness.

    Zuo Long Wan treats direct gaze and internal issues.

    Zuo Pan Long, which is wild dove feces, combined with Bai Jiang Can (white silkworm) and fish bladder (each five qian), and one qian of Xiong Huang. Grind to a powder, make into rice pills the size of jujube, and take fifteen pills with warm wine. If internal symptoms persist, use half of the previously mentioned powder and add half a qian of Ba Dou Shuang. Make rice pills the size of Wutong (Chinese parasol tree) seeds, adding one pill each time. Gradually increase until favorable results are achieved. Afterwards, take harmonizing medicine.

    Jiang Piao Wan treats tetanus that enters the interior, marked by fright and spasms, with internal stagnation of the viscera.

    Ingredients include Jiang Piao (fish bladder, finely crushed and fried), wild dove feces (fried), Bai Jiang Can (white silkworm) (each half a tael), one qian of Xiong Huang, one pair of centipedes, and one tael of Tian Ma.

    Grind into a powder, divide into three parts: two parts into rice pills the size of jujube coated with Zhu Sha; one part into one qian of Ba Dou Shuang, also made into rice pills. For each dose, take twenty pills with Zhu Sha and one with Ba Dou, gradually increasing until favorable results are achieved, then stop taking the initial pills.[142p]

The first formula with Nanshen, Banxia, Caowu, and Chuanwu is for treating tetanus with cold phlegm and a weak pulse.

    Surgery for falls and trauma with sharp instruments, bamboo, and wood injuries.

    Single prescription.[143p]

    • For wounds from a fall on a sharp edge: cover with incense ash to stop the bleeding and promote healing of the flesh.

    • If the bleeding from a gold wound does not stop: soak in cold water, and it will cease.

    • If the gold wound is severe: take water mixed with earthworm feces the size of a thumb for three doses daily.

    • For raised scars: use a hot tile to frequently press the area.

    • For bleeding from a gold wound: do not apply medicine too early, as it may lead to internal rot of the flesh; simply use equal parts of yellow ochre and talc as a powder to apply. Another method: apply powdered mica, which works remarkably well. Another method: apply powdered white peony. Another method: use dust from a mortar mixed with garlic for rubbing; garlic may be omitted. Another method: crush fresh perilla leaves and mulberry leaves together to apply.

    • For internal bleeding from a gold wound: take half a bean-sized amount of realgar, and drink five qian of urine; all the blood will turn to water. Another method: take powdered peony root and drink it, with a pinch the size of three fingers; it will immediately stop the bleeding. Another method: take the blood that oozes from the wound, mix with water, and drink.

    • If bleeding from a gold wound persists: mix cold stone and pitch into a powder, and apply it dry, ensuring it does not come into contact with water. Another method: apply powdered galls. If the individual is breathless, take two qian of powdered galls mixed with a small amount of dragon bone powder, boil and drink; it will be effective immediately.[144p]
      For bleeding from gold wounds: Take the bark of an old fir tree, burn it, grind it into a powder, and apply it. Alternatively, mix it with egg white and apply; it will heal in one or two days.

    Another method: Scrape white sandalwood powder and apply, which can also relieve pain.

    Another method: Mix equal parts of frankincense, gall, and copper flower into a powder for application. You may also scrape frankincense off a porcelain tile and grind it into powder.

    For bleeding from gold wounds: Use half a pound of pomegranate flowers and one liter of lime, crush and dry them in the shade; apply a small amount each time, and it will stop immediately.

    For bleeding from gold wounds: Mix a small amount of asphalt powder with fresh copper filings, and combining them will cause an instant cure.

    If bleeding does not stop and there is suffocation: Take half a tael of cattail pollen and drink it down with hot wine.

    Another method: Grind sorrow grass and apply it to the bleeding area.

    If bleeding from gold wounds does not stop: Apply raw flour; it will heal in five to seven days.

    Another method: Mix leek juice with slaked lime, dry it daily, and apply it as a powder; it is effective.

    Another method: Crush barnyard millet roots and apply them, or mix the powdered form to stop bleeding, and it is very effective.

    Another method: Soak green onions, roast them until soft, press out the juice, and apply it; it will stop immediately.

    Another method: Apply powdered liverwort to stop pain and bleeding.

    Another method: Crush plantain leaves and apply.[145p]

    For Falls and Fractures: Use half a sheng of millet, twenty pieces of Momordica (bitter melon), and half a tael of Banxia, along with a handful of women's hair and a small bundle of green onion whites.     For Falls and Fractures (Alternative Recipe): Use one sheng of glutinous rice, half a sheng of chopped soapwort, and a hundred copper coins, fry until half charred black, remove the coins, grind into powder, and mix with good wine to form a paste, then apply thickly to the affected area for effective results.

    For Bone Injuries: Use vinegar to soak rotten soap and apply it thickly, binding with cloth. For sprains, mix vinegar with pingwei powder and apply.

    For Setting Bones: Use one tael and two qian of vinegar-soaked five-zhu coins, and three taels of black chicken bones, grind finely and mix. For lower body ailments, take four qian before meals; for upper body ailments, take two and a half qian frequently after meals. One recipe includes frankincense and myrrh.

    Guaranteed Effective Wine: For treating deep wounds with wind or rebound injuries, use four cloves of garlic crushed and topped, with one sheng of ash-free wine. Boil the garlic until very soft, then consume five he for each serving, ensuring to sweat shortly thereafter for recovery.[159p]
    Tetanus is like magic: Take a larva from a dung heap, and you can also find it on rotting straw. Grip its spine and wait for it to spit water, then smear this on the wound. You will feel a numbness, and sweating will immediately occur, leading to recovery. This has been tested and proven effective. The larva should be returned to its original place without harming it.

    For treating strong reactions from gunshot wounds: Combine yellow soybeans and one measure of chicken feces. Fry the soybeans until they are charred black, then add the chicken feces and continue to fry. While hot, pour it into three sheng (about 0.9 liters) of wine, cover tightly for a long time, then filter out the dregs. Take five he (about 0.5 liters) at a time; if you walk five miles, take another dose, which induces sweating and is beneficial. If not healed, continue to take until sweating occurs as required. After taking, it is advisable to consume hot ginger porridge.

    For maggots developing in rotten gunshot wounds: Use alum and sprinkle it on the wound to kill them instantly.

    For needles stuck in the flesh: Apply a piece of lard on paper, about the size of a coin, and change it every two days; after three to five changes, it will come out.

    For bamboo or wood embedded in the flesh, which cannot be removed with a needle: Seal it with human tooth dirt, and it will not rot. This has been repeatedly tested and verified.

    For human bite wounds: Take one piece of turtle shell and one piece of soft-shelled turtle shell, burn them, grind them, and apply the powder.

    For a bite on the finger: Soak it in hot urine overnight for complete healing.[160p]
    Acupuncture

    The "Suwen" states: When a person falls or suffers a setback, bad blood remains inside, causing abdominal fullness and swelling, making it difficult to move forward or backward. First, administer beneficial medicine. This affects the Jueyin meridian above and the Shaoyin collateral below. Puncture below the inner ankle of the foot, causing blood to flow from the vessels in front of the bone, and puncture the dorsal artery of the foot. If this does not help, puncture each of the three points on the back of the hand until blood is seen. Puncture the left side for issues on the right, and vice versa. For those who are easily saddened, startled, or unhappy, puncture as per the right side.

    The "Lingshu" states: When there is a fall or setback, bad blood remains inside. If there is great anger, the qi rises without descending, accumulating below the ribs and thus harming the liver. Additionally, a stroke or being hit can occur; for instance, if one is drunk and sweats in the wind, it harms the spleen. Furthermore, headache cannot be treated by meridian points. If struck and there is internal bad blood, and if the pain has not subsided, one can puncture laterally, but not distantly. If the body is injured and there is excessive bleeding due to stroke or cold, if there is a fall, the limbs become weak and slack, termed 'body slack.' Treat the area below the navel, three inches below the navel, which corresponds to the Yangming and Taiyin, and this is the Guanyuan point.

    Medical Cases

    The "History of the Yuan" states: Bu Zhier, under the command of Yuan Taizu, was shot multiple times during a campaign against the Hui people, and his body was filled with blood. Taizu ordered a cow to be taken, its abdomen opened, and the wounded individual placed inside to soak in warm blood. After a while, he recovered.

    Li Ting, under Bie Yan, was wounded in the left ribs by cannonfire and had an arrow penetrate his chest, nearly resulting in death. Bie Yan ordered the abdomen of a water buffalo to be opened, and he was placed inside. After a long time, he recovered.[161p]
    The "Ben Shi Fang" states: During the Xuanhe era, there was a royal physician in a certain kingdom who abruptly received a summons from the emperor to attend to a Buddhist monk. Upon examination, the physician found that the monk had already succumbed to death. When questioned about the cause of death, the attendants were at a loss and terrified. After a long while, two or three elderly attendants arrived, weeping as they approached the sedan chair, and only then did they reveal the truth: he had fallen while chasing after a butterfly, descending from the white sky, which resulted in his death. The physician explained that the injuries were from a fall and belonged to the category of external injuries. He wanted to clarify further but feared uncertainty in the future. Upon another inspection, he noticed a faint breath. Suddenly, he remembered that he had a scented pill in his medicine pouch. He hurriedly took half a tael and heated it over a fire, removing the brain and musk, then ground it with half a liter of wine to administer. By the third watch of the night, the monk finally moaned in agony, and by the fifth watch, he expelled a large quantity of dark blood. After a few days of treatment, he finally recovered.

    Cui Jishi was recently serving as a judge with Li Baozhen in Zelu. Li Xiang had been striking a ball with a cue when a general inadvertently struck him with his staff, resulting in an injury to Li's thumb, which split his nail. In a hurry, he requested a golden knife and medicine to wrap around it, and despite the pain, he forced himself to sit up and repeatedly asked for wine, drinking several cups. As he consumed too much, his complexion turned increasingly pale, yet he bore the pain without complaint. One soldier suggested using freshly cut green onions, which were then heated over sugar and ashes, peeled, and split open to extract the juice. This was applied to the injury, and the warming of the onions was repeated several times. After three applications, his complexion turned red, and soon after he mentioned that the pain had subsided. They repeated this process over ten times, using the heated onions and their juice, and eventually finished the meal in laughter and conversation.[162p]
    The "Confucian Door to Filial Piety" states: A person from Dai traveled and passed through the old city of Xi. He saw a man beaten with a rod, suffering from painful sores, the poison inside him causing a block in the throat, unable to open his mouth, and unable to take in gruel or medicine. After a month of futile treatments, he resigned himself to death. The man from Dai first used a mixture of Three Holy Powders to expel the greenish bile and blockage in the throat, using about half a large jar. Next, he administered over a hundred pills of a purging medicine to remove the foul, dry filth, which took up another large jar. Then he decocted a few qian of the Tongsheng Powder to be taken hot, followed by a sour, spicy soup with scallions and vinegar to induce sweating. Soon, vomiting and diarrhea occurred, and the man survived. This method can be employed for rescue.

    The "Xue Ji Medical Case" states: A man suffered from injuries caused by a fall, experiencing bloating and pressure in both sides, a desire to cough but could not, a metallic taste in the mouth, swelling and pain throughout the body, fatigue, loss of appetite, and a pronounced thirst with a strong pulse, indicating blood depletion and agitation. He was treated with a mixture of children's urine wine, and while needling the affected area, much dark blood and rotten flesh were drawn out. Suddenly, he experienced fever and agitation with sweating, followed by taking three doses of a single ginseng decoction which slightly mitigated the symptoms. Additional medications to tonify qi and blood and clear liver fire were administered in several doses, allowing for slight improvement in appetite. Later, he continued alternating doses of the single ginseng decoction, leading to the resolution of all symptoms and increased appetite, but he could not sleep well. He used Guizhi Decoction adding gardenia and bamboo shavings in four doses, promoting sound sleep. Due to mental fatigue, he experienced thirst and spontaneous sweating, with a weak, rapid pulse, so he was given two doses of Donggui Decoction to nourish the blood, bringing him stability. He also took a modified version of the Comprehensive Ginseng Decoction, excluding Chuanxiong and adding wheat, five-flavored herbs, peony, earth bone, ma huang root, and fried floating wheat in several doses until sweating ceased, and the necrotic flesh began to ulcerate. After over twenty additional doses, new flesh began to grow.[163p]
    A person has a wound from a stick. The injured area is swollen and painful, but the pain doesn't subside. I said: "The stagnant blood is inside; it should be urgently needled."     A patient experienced swelling and pain, applying a cooling medicine intending to dissipate the stagnant blood, but this resulted in both buttocks and legs becoming cold, with the blood stagnating and congealing, causing distension and discomfort in the chest and abdomen.     Wounds from Insects and Beasts

    From the book "Thousand Gold Prescriptions" by Sun Simiao (Tang Dynasty)

    General Discussion

    Whenever encountering any poisonous creatures or stings, one must not develop a revulsion towards them or kill them. If one rashly kills them, later one will surely suffer from the poison of the sting, and treatment will be difficult. Be cautious, be cautious!

    Rabies

    In late spring and early summer, when dogs frequently go mad, one must admonish the weak and small to carry a stick for protection. If one tries to prevent an attack and fails, it will not exceed the remedy of moxibustion. Among a hundred days, if there is not a single day missed, then one may escape disaster. If, upon first encountering a wound, it seems to heal without pain, and one thinks it has recovered, this is the most terrifying sign. Great calamity will arise, and death will come unexpectedly. Whenever a rabid dog bites someone, it causes that person to become mad as well; their spirit has already become detached, how can one be aware? Just watch closely; if during moxibustion the fire is applied for one degree, and the heart feels distinctly awake and clear, then one realizes that once bitten, one is indeed mad, thus it is imperative to understand this deeply. This illness is severe, yet many in the world treat it lightly and do not regard it seriously, which leads to deaths occurring regularly. When I first learned medicine, I did not take it up professionally; there were those who encountered this ailment but when they consulted me, I genuinely did not know how to respond, resulting in several patients dying under my care.[176p]
    From this point on, I resolutely dedicated myself to study, and having solved it, all those in charge became better. It became evident that there are no good doctors in the world, and those who die wrongfully are many; this is not an exaggeration. Therefore, future learners should not stop at this method. I believe all medical prescriptions must be contemplated deeply, attentively studied, and earnestly learned to gain thorough understanding. One should not think that knowing one or two methods is sufficient; that would be a great self-deception.

    Whenever a dog bites a person, symptoms should appear within seven days; if they do not appear after twenty-one days, then the person is in the clear but should still be cautious for over a hundred days. Every seven days, one should drink one to two sheng of leek juice, and one should avoid eating dog meat and silkworm pupae for life; consuming these will provoke the disease, leading to inevitable death. While the wound is not healed, one should refrain from eating raw fish and all rich, cold foods; it is fine to eat steamed fish with rice, but not from rich dishes. Drinking alcohol should be avoided, ideally for over a year.[177p]
    The Qusheng (a type of insect)

    Whenever the shadow of the Qusheng urinates on someone, it causes diseases and sores. Its symptoms include sudden sharp pains in the body, akin to a thorn prick or the sting of an insect, followed by the emergence of small bumps that appear like the seeds of a berry, with red edges and a center filled with white pus resembling millet, causing intense pain to the flesh. The body experiences severe chills and high fever, with serious cases affecting the waist, sides, and chest.

    The treatment method, upon first noticing the illness, is to grind rhino horn and apply it to stop the poison, treating it as one would with fire elixirs. During the Wude period in June, I contracted this ailment. After five to six days, I felt unsettled and my condition did not improve with other treatments. Someone else advised me to draw the shape of the Qusheng on the ground and carefully remove the soil from its abdomen with a knife, mixing it with saliva to make a paste and applying it. After reapplying, I was cured. This illustrates the interconnectedness of all things in the world, though the reasons remain unknown.[178p]
    In Jiangnan, there is a type of poisonous insect known as the short fox or the tian. This insect resembles a beetle. According to "Wai Tai," it is pitch black, shaped like a large flying insect, with a long horn extending from its mouth, resembling the yoke of a crossbow. At the end of this horn, it curves like a bent bow, using air as an arrow to attack people based on the water's force. Sometimes, people hear it making a noise in the water and must fully submerge its mouth in water to attack. It is afraid of geese, which can eat it.

    Initially, when symptoms appear, there are chills and shivering, with alternating hot and cold sensations, resembling a cold or being struck down. The person may be unable to speak, feeling slightly better in the morning but worsening in the evening, suffering from chaotic chills and heat. These are the symptoms. If not treated promptly within three to four days, those infected easily succumb by the seventh day. At first, there are no sores, but only the chills and shivering. Eventually, sores form that resemble a mix of weevil and urine, similar to boils and sores. There are three types of sores caused by this insect: one is dark black like a dye, with surrounding skin entirely red, which might feel prickly as if pierced by thorns; another type develops into a sore that persists for a long time, accompanied by intermittent chills and fever; the third type appears as if burned with fire and is the most urgent, killing within several days.

    Whenever one encounters toxic insects in mountainous waters, those wading through might be affected like a shooting victim without a weapon. The diagnostic method involves initial chills, mild headache, pain around the eyes, inner agitation, shaking of the limbs, tightness in the waist and back, and pain in the knees. They may also experience alternating feelings of heat and cold, with an overwhelming desire to sleep, waking up with severe symptoms in the evening, and cold extremities.[179p]
    In two or three days, worms develop in the abdomen, feeding on the lower parts of the body, leading to sores in the anus that are painless and itchless, causing the person to remain unaware. If not treated urgently, after six or seven days, pus will emerge from the lower parts, the worms will start to eat the organs, and intense heat and toxins will lead to uncontrollable diarrhea. After eight or nine days, even skilled doctors will be unable to treat it. When recognized, one must examine the lower parts urgently; if there are sores that are bright red as if cut meat, this indicates Yang poison and is most urgent; if the sores resemble fish teeth, this indicates Yin poison and can be treated with less urgency. Both can be deadly, but not exceeding twenty days. To determine whether it is water poison or not, one should prepare five to six liters of broth, adding five liters of crushed garlic into the broth, ensuring it does not get too hot, and then straining it for bathing. If the body exhibits red spots due to the water poison, this confirms it; otherwise, it must be treated for another ailment.[180p]
    In the streams and sources of Jiangdong and Jiangnan, there is a worm known as the Short Fox Worm, also called the Shooting Worker. This worm is blind but has keen hearing; found in mountain springs and streams, it can detect human voices and shoots poison from its mouth, hence the name Shooting Worker. For those affected by this small, mildly toxic worm, when pursued, and if the worm hits a person's shadow, it does not immediately cause sores. Instead, symptoms appear first with chills and fever; the body dislikes the cold, physical strength may seem tense, headaches and eye pain occur, and there may be a constant cough with labored breathing. In the morning, there may be brief recovery, only to return to chills and fever in the evenings. Sometimes, when afflicted with cold damage, a person may feel as if struck by a corpse, becoming unable to speak, and the symptoms persist in this manner. Those unfamiliar with the local landscape, who do not frequently wander in mountain waters, may mistake these signs for cold damage from external forces, leading to improper treatments. As the poison intensifies and sores develop, it may further be mistaken for swellings; to the extent that nausea and vomiting of blood occurs, they might even fear it to be sorcery or poison, resulting in serious troubles. Now, this description delineates its characteristics to clarify its symptoms from those of cold damage.[181p]
    Essentials of Diagnosis and Treatment 【Ming Dynasty - Dai Sigong】

    Injury from Poisonous Insects and Snakes

    For injuries caused by poisonous insects and snakes, chew white atractylodes finely and apply it to the wound, and also take it mixed with alcohol. For centipede injuries, apply chicken droppings. For worm injuries, use the burnt ash of fern leaves mixed with fragrant oil for application. For dog bites, use ground tiger bone. For cat bites, apply mint. For bee and scorpion stings, chew ginseng and apply it, or use ground crab shells, burnt to retain their essence, mixed with honey for application. In all cases of injury from vicious creatures, it is also good to quickly cauterize the wound with moxa a few times.

    Xue's Medical Cases 【Ming Dynasty - Xue Ji】

    Accidental Swallowing of Leeches

    To treat the accidental swallowing of leeches, consuming honey can lead to recovery. If live leeches are thrown into honey, they will dissolve into liquid, as repeatedly observed. One book states that leeches found in wells can be eliminated by throwing in white horse bones, which has also been tested successfully. Leeches, or bloodsuckers, even if dead and ground to powder, can come back to life upon contact with water. Their ingestion can be quite harmful, and the aforementioned treatment has always been effective.[182p]
    Snake Enters the Seven Orifices

    Whenever a snake enters the seven orifices, split the snake's tail and insert several grains of Sichuan pepper, sealing it with paper. The snake will exit on its own. Then brew and drink ginseng broth; alternatively, consume wine and garlic to combat internal toxins. If bitten by a snake, eat garlic and drink wine; also use crushed garlic to apply to the wound and combine it with moxa for cauterization; the poison will be naturally resolved. This applies to all cases of venomous insect bites.

    Treatment of Caterpillar Injury

    In spring and summer months, beneath trees and in the gaps, there exists a type of striped caterpillar, which is extremely toxic. If a person makes contact, its hairs penetrate into the skin and flesh, reaching the bones. Initially, there may be slight itching on the skin, which gradually turns into pain; after several days, the external itching persists while internal pain develops. Scratching can worsen the condition, potentially leading to rotting flesh and a threat to life. This is known as the poison of the penetrating worker, and no medications are effective.

    Use about a bowl of good fermented soybeans and half a cup of clear oil, mix and mash the soybeans, and apply a thick layer to the painful and itchy areas. After some time, the bean scent will reach the bones and draw out the caterpillar hairs, which will be visible. After removing the soybeans, bury them in the ground. Boil fragrant white angelica soup to wash the painful areas. If the flesh has already rotted, use crushed cuttlefish bone or fishbone as a powder to apply, and it will heal. For injuries from insects, licorice works wonders. Chew finely and apply it to the mouth for immediate relief. In present-day Suzhou, beneath Tiger Hill, local families depend on planting trees, and there are no insects within a ten-mile radius, likely due to the use of licorice juice to sprinkle on the trees.[183p]
    Stone Chamber's Secret Prescriptions
    [Qing Dynasty - Chen Shiduo]
    Treatment for Insect and Animal Bites
    When a person is bitten by a tiger, blood will flow profusely, and the wound will immediately fester, causing unbearable pain. Quickly use pork to apply to the wound; as the meat melts, replace it frequently. Additionally, use one pound of earthworm finely ground, combined with three taels of the root of Notopterygium, and four taels of Sofu, mix well. Apply as needed; the bleeding will stop and the pain will subside. Earthworm cools the blood, Sofu alleviates pain, and the root of Notopterygium stops bleeding; the combination of these three ingredients is therefore remarkably effective.

    Realgar Disinfectant Ointment
    [From "Precious Mirror"]
    For intolerable scorpion stings:
    Realgar, ½ tael; 3 qian of Croton; 1 tael of raw alum.
    Grind these into a fine powder. Mix with ½ tael of yellow wax, melt together, and form small pills the size of jujubes. When using, hold the pill in the flame until heated, then apply the melted ointment to the sting; the pain will stop immediately.

    First Powder
    For pain from scorpion stings:
    One character of Pinellia, finely ground; one character of Realgar, ground separately; one Croton (peeled) turned to paste. Mix these three ingredients together thoroughly.[184p]
    Holy Remedies for Snake Bites and Scorpion Stings

    For treating snake bites and scorpion stings, the method is remarkable:

    • Three qians of realgar, one qian of faith (or trust), and forty-nine grains each of soapberry and purgative bean; a small amount of earplug and musk.
      On May 5, in a place without the sounds of chickens, dogs, or women, without speaking, pound into a fine powder, seal it in an apricot kernel, and prick out the painful area with a needle for significant effect.

    For treating injuries from venomous snakes:

    • Five qians each of asarum and fragrant white artemisia, and two qians of realgar.
      Grind into a powder, add a small amount of musk, and take two qians with warm wine for effect.

    For various snake bites, apply this to the person who has captured the snake. The medicinal properties are effective even if not complete:

    • Ingredients include large and small indigo, fragrant wood, leaves of the black oak, fire-cooked grass, mountain fern flesh, mountain dragon, earth centipede, asparagus, white peony, and fragrant herb.
      Grind these into a fine powder, mix with fragrant wood and dilute with raw white wine. Apply the residue to the bite area for cumulative effect.

    Cicada Flower Powder for dog bites in summer and various injuries, especially in cases of severe maggot infestation, where the stench is unbearable:

    • One ounce of snake cicada skin, burnt until it is charred. Half an ounce each of cicada shell and indigo, and two and a half qians of asarum.
      Grind into a fine powder, take three qians mixed with wine. If livestock are injured and develop sores, administer with wine. For dog bites, mix with fermented dough; it will turn all maggots into water, and flies will not dare to land again. Additionally, mix with dry powedered cold-water stone.[185p]
      Ding Feng San (Settling Wind Powder): For treating dog bites, first rinse the mouth with a wash of water and syrup, dry it with cotton, and apply medicine. If there are no further outbreaks, the effect is remarkable.

    Fu Wei San (扶危散): For treating rabid dog bites, expelling poison.

    Wild Kudzu Ointment treats poisonous nodes caused by arrows, and those afflicted by malevolent illnesses.
